DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON INDUSTRY, SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beddall Mr D.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology, I present the report of the Committee entitled The North West Shelf-A sea of lost opportunities?-first report on Australian industry participation in the second stage of the North West Shelf project-together with the minutes of proceedings and evidence received by the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-This is the third report presented by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology and the first report on the North West Shelf. The report is entitled, I think appropriately, A sea of lost opportunities?. When the Committee set out to look at this, very few members of the Committee understood what was involved with the North West Shelf project in terms of its size and scope. I officially put on record my appreciation to the joint venture partners, and Woodside Offshore Petroleum Pty Ltd in particular, for the cooperation they gave to the Committee. I assure Woodside that there has been no witch-hunt in trying to lay blame for the lack of Australian industry participation in the North West Shelf at the door of those predominantly overseas controlled companies.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a great question to be asked about these very large resource projects not only in terms of the income generated for Australia by the export of natural gas from the North West Shelf to Japan and its supply to the Western Australian domestic market, but also in considering, as the Committee has done, what there is for Australian industry. The Committee is critical in many ways of the approach taken by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. Some of the recommendations in the report refer specifically to how it feels the Department can improve its game in gaining an overall benefit to Australia from very large natural resource projects.

There has been a great upsurge in exploration in the North West Shelf. The north-west of Australia is very much on the verge of establishing a new industry. With the Carnarvon Basin, the Timor Sea and now the agreement with Indonesia on the Timor Gap, Australia faces the prospect of substantial oil and gas offshore fields. We must now take the opportunity to ensure that Australian industry participates in these projects for the benefit of Australian industry.

There are many short term negatives for Australia in these projects. The scope and size of the projects are quite mind-boggling. The current North West Shelf project being operated by Woodside will have a $14 billion price tag, $8.6 billion being spent by the time the Goodwyn platform is complete. The initial impact of this on the terms of trade and balance of payments is quite large. A large proportion of this infrastructure is imported when the Committee feels that Australian industry can participate in and benefit from such large scale projects. We have called the report A sea of lost opportunities? because the Committee as a whole feels that over the years governments have looked only at the export of the natural product, be it gas or oil, rather than at the integrated performance that can be generated for Australian industry.

Australia has had a cultural cringe over many years that it cannot produce high technology or world standard projects. We as a Committee discount this and think that in recent times Australian industry has shown that it can conduct projects of world scale. There are two classic examples-the submarine project that the Government is undertaking and the decision by the Government to build the frigates in Australia-of projects of a scale and scope similar to the projects of the North West Shelf. We think that Australian industry for the first time has been able to quantify what the additional cost will be, particularly for the frigate project. In evidence we were told that the premium that had to be paid to gain 82 per cent of Australian industry participation was 4 per cent. When we talk about projects of this scale, it is not a large premium to pay.

The Committee looked at a number of Australian companies which are at the forefront of world technology in fabrication, particularly Hu-Metal Engineering Pty Ltd in Victoria, which has developed a new rolling technology that could be appropriate for the development of piles and platforms not only in the North West Shelf but throughout the world. That company has patented this rolling technology and it is of world standard.

I said earlier that in the report we were critical, and remain critical, of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. We were amazed at some of the evidence given by the Department and in particular at the fact that there had been no consultation that we could see between the Department of Primary Industries and Energy and the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce. We feel that the two departments should work closely together so that Australian industry can provide the necessary jobs and also develop world-class technologies that can give Australia an advantage and an enhanced industrial base.

The problem we found in all these projects was that, when assessing benefits to Australia, the Department had assessed only the resource benefit and not the total benefit, which is much more important. If Australia is to be an industrialised nation and not just an exporter of commodities-as we have always been told-we must value add. One of the ways we can do that is by providing a large measure of Australian industry participation. The Committee recommended that we try to gain some definition of Australian content. We were told that there is 72 per cent Australian content in the North Rankin project on the North West Shelf. In fact, much of that Australian content was in infrastructure in providing and building the necessary buildings and storage facilities that could only ever be done in this country anyway.

What is much more important in developing these types of projects is that we get the intellectual capacity and the intellectual qualities of design and technology, and we have made a number of recommendations in this regard. We have also looked in some detail at examples overseas, particularly the British example, in Margaret Thatcher's United Kingdom, where even in that free enterprise mentality the Government is very insistent on a high level of British industry participation. Something like 82 per cent British industry participation was achieved in the North Sea. That is not done by legislation; it is done by consultation and cohesion to ensure that British industry can participate fairly and equitably.

One of the great problems for Australian industry is that, in the design and technology sections, specifications can be written in such a way that it is very difficult for Australian industries to comply with the specifications. We have recommended in this report that international standards be set right at the start of these projects so that Australian companies can tender on a competitive basis. We have also recommended in this report that early notice be given of major development projects and that Australian companies know well in advance what projects are coming up. The Department of Primary Industries and Energy already requires that a proposal be put to the Department fairly early in the piece, and we feel that requirement should be made more public so that Australian companies know what is coming up.

We have done a lot of work in the compilation of this report in a reasonably short space of time and covered quite a distance around Australia. I would like to put on record my thanks to the other members of the Committee from all parties in this Parliament who have put a great deal of effort into what has been a very difficult task. I also put on record my thanks to the Committee secretariat-Doug Capp, Chris Paterson and Jodie Kiermaier-for the excellent work they did in producing the report under very difficult circumstances.

I do not want to take up a deal of time because, in the spirit of bipartisanship that has pervaded this Committee, many members wish to speak, and I do feel that that is the way these sorts of reports should be handled. The inquiry has been particularly informative for all members of the Committee. When this project started none of us knew what a jacket or a pile was. Now we are all experts in technology and we know what the make-ups of an offshore platform are. Through the good grace of Woodside Offshore Petroleum Pty Ltd, we were able to visit the North Rankin platform on the North West Shelf, and that was a very informative exercise. I commend the report to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur Mr F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I support the Chairman of the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology, the honourable member for Rankin (Mr Beddall), in tabling the report entitled The North West Shelf-A sea of lost opportunities? I also echo the sentiments of the Chairman about the cooperative way in which the Committee operated in tabling what I think is a very good and interesting report. As the Chairman said, the North West Shelf project is really quite an exciting project. Capital expenditure of $14 billion is foreshadowed. It is a major export earner, $700m having been spent on exploration, which is something that a lot of Australians have overlooked because they have been overwhelmed by the magnitude of the project and the way it is now being constructed. It is a world-class project in terms of design and the risk that the joint venturers have undertaken in that difficult natural climate.

SPEECH.PARA: The key element of the project that came through to the Committee was that the natural gas provided a base load of energy for Western Australia and Japan. Western Australia will enjoy natural gas for 20 years and Japan will get 16 per cent of its natural gas from the project by 1995. Australia will have 40 per cent of its energy requirements from that source.

As the Chairman mentioned, we visited the North Rankin platform, which was quite an exciting and elevating experience. That platform, which is some 125 miles offshore, has survived `a once in 300 years' gale and the design of the platform withstood those tremendous pressures. At that time there were 23-metre waves and the cyclone passed over the top of the platform. The Goodwyn field, in the construction of which we had a major interest-and that is what the report is all about-has a bigger platform with a 17,000-tonne jacket and a 15,000-tonne module on top of the jacket, indicating the scale of operation that Australian manufacturers are being asked to tender for.

The Committee was particularly interested in the role of the Government, and the Chairman has made reference to the Committee's apprehensions and concerns that some government departments were not fully aware of the implications of the project. The Government is controlling the leases of the offshore operations and the production licences. The report suggests that governments should be aware of the implications and evaluate these large projects, especially in view of the overseas borrowings, the foreign expertise and equipment required and the debt servicing requirements of such projects. The North West Shelf project will receive income of $41 billion over 20 years, of which the Government will receive $10 billion from royalties and taxes in the same period. There should be a set of criteria-and we set that out in the reports-for assessing these bigger projects.

I was personally particularly interested in the viability and risk and the regulatory aspects of governments in this whole area of resource exploration and the setting up of these particular projects. The North West Shelf project was considered to be marginal by the joint venturers when they made their final decision to proceed. However, they did indicate to the Committee that they took a 20-year view of oil and energy prices, and the oil companies discounted their capital investment by 20 per cent to make sure that they were on the right side of the ledger.

The report mentions that the construction period was a matter of some debate with a number of witnesses. The project period of 27 months seemed to be under a certain amount of discussion, especially having in mind the cyclone season and the very important `window of opportunity' that was often quoted to us at the stage when the jacket had to be put in place, when the seasonal conditions were acceptable. A lot of concern was expressed by witnesses about the industrial disputes that might upset the whole program. However, we were encouraged by the attitudes of unions and management in that they were cooperating and trying very hard to overcome the difficulties that had been encountered in other projects in north-west Australia. Our view is that there are very encouraging signs from unions and management that they were sorting out their problems before the project got under way.

As I mentioned earlier, the base load operation meant that there had to be a very important emphasis on quality, and the Committee was looking at ways of improving the Australian participation and content in the project. The Chairman mentioned that there seemed to be about a 74 per cent content on the project by Australian manufacturers and the Australian work force. The Committee was particularly interested in the quality controls by management, the delays in delivery that might upset the project, the price of the various items of the total project and the safety performances on the construction phase. The reports indicated that there was a very good record on safety by both management and the unions. Of course, the other problems that were highlighted were the shortage of skilled engineers here in Australia and the lack of infrastructure that was available for these one-off projects.

The capability and capacity of Australian industry to compete is the key element of our report. We are suggesting that Australians have the capacity to compete. However, the evidence indicated that when the overseas option was available there was a tendency for the joint venturers to take that option rather than have a good look at the Australian possibility. The problems of fabrication of the jacket and module were, as I mentioned, constrained by the lack of onshore facilities and the lack of big cranes to shift these particularly heavy fabricated pieces from the construction site.

Finally, Dr John White of Australian Marine Engineering Consolidated Ltd gave the Committee some intimation of what can be done. As the Chairman mentioned, it is now building frigates at the Williamstown dockyards. That is quite an inspirational story of what major Australian engineering firms can do. Dr John White has experience in the North West Shelf area and has indicated that big projects can be completed. The frigate project indicates the possibility that this can be done. Dr White made the point that when Australians do big projects, the supplying, support and maintenance of fabricated materials means that the plant is in position and that the supplier can service it over the next 20 years.

I thank the Chairman and members of the Committee for their cooperation and I thank the members of staff for an excellent report. I hope that the report will encourage Australian heavy manufacturers to change their attitude to Australian projects over the next 20 years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris Mr A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I join with previous speakers in commending to the House the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology's report entitled The North West Shelf-A sea of lost opportunities? This report has the potential to transform the approach of Australian and overseas companies to the development of Australian resources. The facts that emerged during the inquiry were surprising and disappointing. They reflected a very long period in Australia's economic history where we have focused on resource export and not on the implications of resource development itself.

SPEECH.PARA: When one looks at what the joint venture partners have achieved it is important to make very public and very clear that their standing with Australian manufacturers is very low, their credibility as to how they have approached the project is suspect and there is a great deal more that they could and should do if they truly desire to be good corporate citizens in this country. I want to give an example of that. We are aware of the cost pressures on resource sales, whether they be coal, gas or oil. We are not so aware of the fact that the major competition comes from the same companies that export from Australia, and the fact that this is forcing down energy prices. This affects in particular the gas field in the north where gas reserves are being developed by partners in the North West Shelf project. It is vital to recognise that, whether the company is Shell Australia, Shell Malaysia or Shell in some other part of the world, it is still Shell. Clearly Shell's corporate interests will always override what many of us see as Australia's national interest.

It is also important to recognise the obvious quid pro quo in marketing and manufacturing. There is no doubt in my mind-and, I would think, the minds of many people on the Committee and in the wider manufacturing community-that a great deal of the tendering relates to the selling of the product. I do not think there is any question but that the manufacture of ships for the transport of gas in Japan relates quite specifically and virtually totally to the fact that Japanese companies are the buyers of the gas. In other words, they say, `If we do not build your ships we will not buy your gas'. So a large part of the value of gas sales goes back to Japan through construction value for those ships. I cannot be persuaded that the ships could not be built somewhere else in the world-perhaps even in Australia-at a lower price. It is no coincidence that so much of the manufacturing flow-on from this project goes to the countries that buy the product. There may be valid and justifiable reasons for things of that nature but those reasons are not public or visible.

If one compares Australia's performance in projects such as this with, say, that of Norway, a country of just over a quarter of our size, and looks at the chemical and manufacturing industries, it is obvious that we have been a very open and easy country to deal with and exploit. The fact that, despite many months of serious attempts to probe into the question, we still do not know the net effect on the Australian balance of payments leaves a question mark hanging over the credibility of the joint venture partners. I asked them quite specifically and directly whether they would advise us of their debt servicing costs, their expected expatriation of profits and expected expenditure in both transport and manufacturing overseas so that we on the Committee and in the Parliament could say that even though we have not done as well as we could with manufacturing we have gained X billion dollars in net benefit in terms of Australia's trade. The joint venturers declined to provide the information that they obviously must have. That was their choice. By making that choice I believe they leave themselves in a very poor situation in regard to their corporate image and credibility in this country. If we cannot obtain the manufacturing and skills transfer, clearly we should obtain a benefit to our balance of payments and net standing in the world. We appear to do poorly in both aspects.

Recommendation 3 of the Committee recommends, for projects of this nature, the establishment of a new procedure which we refer to as an economic impact statement or assessment. Projects of this magnitude with this capacity to affect our economy and internal industries need to be looked at as total projects, not as relative projects or tax-raising projects or as being employers of X hundred or thousand people. Over decades this country's historical failure to recognise resource development in that way has led to this report being so important.

This report has the potential to transform the way we approach resources development in this country. I do not doubt that many of us believe that that is a vital need. I urge the joint venture partners and other developers and would-be developers of Australian resources to be much more transparent and open, to bring their proposals, plans and expectations to Australia both in the public and industry sectors so that when we accept these projects and endorse them, and they proceed, they do so with us having full knowledge and understanding of all of the implications. The failure at the start of this project for that process to be required has meant that we have encouraged secrecy. Information has been hidden away and we have established precedents as a country that has virtually told developers that we do not expect them to disclose what they are doing, we do not want to know what they are doing, as long as the project appears good on the surface.

The North West Shelf project could be the best project in Australia's history, or it could be the worst. My fear is that it may be the worst. We cannot force the joint venture partners to change their procedures from what they were allowed to set up some 10 or 15 years ago-that is history-but I strongly and strenuously urge them to do so. If they continue to operate in Australia in the way they have in the past I suspect that in years to come they will regret any decision not to change their methodology, become more open and generally embrace and involve Australian companies. This is an important report. I trust and hope that it changes the attitudes of both government departments and developers about the development of Australian resources. I commend the report to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I would like to join with other members of the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology in speaking briefly to the report entitled The North West Shelf-A sea of lost opportunities? I commend the report to the Parliament. I particularly wish to support the words of the Chairman, the honourable member for Rankin (Mr Beddall), and my colleague the honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur). I think it is important for everyone to realise the size of this project. It is enormous. It is probably the first project of its kind in Australia and, as such, has required the development of a lot of new technology and skills which in many cases did not exist in Australia. That development certainly has occurred, and, while certainly a lot of the Australian content in this project refers to infrastructure that has to be made in Australia anyway, nonetheless there is quite a good level of Australian involvement.

SPEECH.PARA: I point out to honourable members that, as the Committee says at the beginning of the report, we received considerable assistance from Woodside Offshore Petroleum Pty Ltd and the joint venture participants of the North West Shelf project. While the Committee was made aware of growing criticism of Woodside and the joint venturers, particularly for not providing sufficient opportunity for Australian industry participation in this project, as we pointed out in the introduction to the report we found that that was not the case. I would have to take a slightly different tack from the previous speaker, the honourable member for Newcastle (Mr Allan Morris). Certainly I disagree with the tone of some of his comments. I do not hold the same fears as the previous speaker about the possibility of this being, I think in this words, `one of the worst projects in our history'.

Putting that aside, as we say in the introduction to the report, Woodside has provided Australian industry with considerable opportunity to participate in the project. Woodside has been very positive in its attempts to assess Australian industry capability and apprise Australian industry of market opportunities. The overall level of Australian industry participation has been equal to that of many other major resource projects. As we point out, Woodside has complied with its obligations as they currently stand. So the question then arises-I do not know that we can immediately find the answer-as to what are reasonable obligations to place on a developer such as Woodside and its joint venture partners in bringing this project to fruition and at the same time provide the maximum opportunity for Australian involvement. As has been pointed out by the Chairman, at the beginning of the inquiry we were under the impression that the Commonwealth departments responsible for resource development and industry policy would be able to provide a great deal of assistance in the conduct of the inquiry. As we point out in the report, this did not prove to be the case. That, in itself, is a fairly strong criticism of those departments.

As mentioned, in the development of the project we have seen the development of considerable expertise. We are pushing to see maximum Australian involvement particularly at the design stage. With a new type of project such as this, it is not surprising that the joint venture partners would want the best available involvement in the world. Since Australia had not been involved in the design of such a project, it was hardly reasonable to expect people to ask Australian engineers to design these things. Nonetheless, having got this type of project up and running, it is important that we ensure that Australians get involved in the design stage of future projects like this one. In fact, we might be able to develop an industry that will service other parts of the world, particularly South East Asia where there are many opportunities.

Another problem facing Australian industry is the difficulty of the costs of transport from eastern Australian to Western Australia. This was evidenced time and again. There are difficulties with transport, both by sea and by land, in trying to get major components across to the North West Shelf. This has shown that Australia's infrastructure, our service industries, our ability to use shipping and land transport, need upgrading. If it takes a project such as this to highlight this point, so be it. Obviously, Western Australia, because of its location, has been the major beneficiary in this regard. That is quite understandable.

I would like briefly to talk about some of the problems that have been highlighted which face Australian manufacturers, particularly when there is no equivalent Australian material, yet an Australian manufacturer, when having to import some material, is still forced to pay some duty. I feel very strongly about this. There was a similar incident in my electorate involving an Australian manufacturer being penalised when trying to compete with overseas manufacturers. Recommendation No. 12 of the report has wider application but certainly has very strong application for Australian industry trying to compete in these sorts of projects. The Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) and the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) should ensure that customs duties are waived where specified materials required for fabrication work are not available in Australia. Likewise, if local manufacturers claim to make an equivalent they must be able to demonstrate compliance with the particular design specifications. The onus is on the two departments and their Ministers to look into this. It is a very significant penalty for Australian manufacturers who are trying to compete.

In winding up my remarks, I reinforce the views of the honourable member for Corangamite in talking about the spin-off to Australian industry in getting involved in this sort of project. The case presented to the Committee by Dr White is very significant and very exciting. I think that all members of the Committee were most impressed with it. They realised the enormous spin-off benefits to Australian industry of getting involved in a project such as the North West Shelf. The other benefit of the project is that it is forcing Australian companies to think globally, to realise that we have to compete in the world, not just locally. Again, that will clean out many cobwebs.

As the Chairman has pointed out, this is a first report. We will be looking to explore further some of the areas we have mentioned in the report. We will obviously be looking for some feedback from those who have assisted with the inquiry. In that way, the approach of the joint venturers, Australian industry and the Government to these sorts of projects will be improved. I too, would like to thank the secretariat. I also commend the Chairman for the way he has conducted this inquiry and look forward to being involved in its next stage.

DEBATE.TITLE: SANDFILLING AT INTERNATIONAL TERMINAL, COMMERCIAL AND OPERATIONAL SITES, BRISBANE AIRPORT

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works, I present the twenty-fifth report of the Committee for 1989, relating to the sandfilling at the international terminal, commercial and operational sites, Brisbane Airport.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The report I have just tabled relates to the preparation of sites for further developments at Brisbane Airport. These include sites for an international terminal and aviation industry infrastructure. This report is the sixth report presented by the Committee regarding developments at Brisbane Airport since 1979. I should also add that the Committee has spent more time examining this project than any other this year. What appeared on the surface to be a reasonably straightforward project developed into a re-examination of the planning philosophy of the Brisbane Airport and the master plan on which it is based.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee is well aware that airports are an extremely sensitive issue in the community and Brisbane is no exception. The Committee recognises that any decision it reaches on this matter is likely to be controversial and arouse strong feelings in the community. Indeed, reflecting this, two members of the Committee have dissented from the final recommendation that the project proceed. The Committee recognises that in many respects future development at Brisbane Airport has been locked in by past developments. The Committee is also conscious that its referral related to a specific project. However, the Committee recognised that the sandfilling project had the possible effect of closing off alternative avenues of development. The Committee therefore took the view that it has a wider responsibility to the Parliament and examined in some detail the basic philosophy of the master plan and issues such as runway directions, length of crosswind runway and noise effects.

As part of its examination the Committee undertook detailed inspections of the airport and environs on 25 July and 10 August. These included the proposed site, the existing international terminal, and an aerial inspection which included the airport, the site for the sand dredging at Middle Banks and a simulated instrument approach to the airport. The Committee also travelled to suburbs south of the city to observe aircraft on landing approach and to experience noise levels.

On balance, the Committee, with the exception of Senator Burns and Senator Devereux, has, somewhat reluctantly, accepted that the sandfilling project should proceed as proposed by the Federal Airports Corporation. In the report the Committee has recommended that the Federal Airports Corporation should undertake a thorough re-examination of the Brisbane Airport master plan before further runway developments are undertaken. In making this recommendation, the Committee has rejected the proposition that extension of the 14/32 crosswind runway to accept heavier aircraft is not feasible.

The Committee has also drawn attention to the measures being taken to minimise the noise impact of aircraft operations at Brisbane Airport. The Committee is aware of the considerable concern expressed to it by residents' groups and by local Federal and State members on the issue of aircraft noise. In conclusion, I thank all members of the Committee for their contribution to the inquiry, which proved to be an extremely complex and difficult one. I commend the report to the House.
