SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is an honour to be able to lead this debate on the second reading of the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 3) on behalf of the Federal Opposition. I am very pleased to be able to announce that the Opposition will fight this Bill tooth and nail on every possible political platform, and upon our return to government we will repeal this insidious attack on individual rights. It is a classic Bill for a Labor Party administration which believes more in collective rights than in individual rights.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill was initiated following a statement from the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) on 18 October 1989 that the Federal Government would move against any State government which tried to implement voluntary student unionism within tertiary institutions in that State. The Minister's proposal comes partly as a response to indications that State governments in New South Wales and Queensland have been seriously considering the introduction of voluntary student unionism. Under the Bill, a State parliament is prevented from outlawing compulsory student unionism and payments to a State are conditional upon that State meeting this Commonwealth condition or requirement.

If a State introduces a ban on compulsory student unionism, it may be required to pay an amount equal to the shortfall to the Commonwealth or alternatively the Commonwealth will reduce the State's general revenue assistance. It is then proposed that the Commonwealth will make payments directly to the affected institutions, thus by-passing the States altogether. In other words, if necessary, the Minister would fund his student mates, minority ratbag groups, directly out of Commonwealth funds, out of the pockets of taxpayers, and freeze the States of funding that they would otherwise be entitled to.

The Government has a very clear motivation for this proposal. Firstly, it will be used as a vehicle by the Minister to claim that he is concerned about the autonomy of higher education institutions. Nothing could be further from the truth. No Federal Minister in the history of our Federation has done more than this Minister to undermine the independence and autonomy of our higher education institutions. If the situation were not so serious, it would be laughable for anybody to suggest that this Minister has any interest whatsoever in institutional autonomy. The whole rationale of his policy is that higher education institutions should be under Canberra's thumb more than ever before. The Minister sets the national priorities and requires institutions to comply with them. He has instituted a series of mechanisms to increase his control over universities. I am very pleased also to announce that upon our return to government the coalition will abolish very many of those controls.

The Minister has also announced his intention to introduce a Bill of rights for universities. In the same statement of 18 October 1989 in which the Minister denies students freedom of association, he has the audacity to announce a charter of academic freedom. In doing so, he acknowledges the veracity of the criticism that his higher education policies have compromised academic freedom. Whilst the announcement confirms concerns about centralised control, it is meaningless when, as was pointed out recently by the Vice-Chancellor of Melbourne University, `all the political processes of control remain in place'. The Minister has constantly used the power of the purse to exercise greater controls. As long as the honourable member for Fremantle (Mr Dawkins) is the Minister, we can be sure that he will continually keep a gun at the head of our institutions to whip them into line and to bully them into meeting his policy objectives. The charter, of course, is in similar vein to this legislation. It is a case of the arsonist declaring the need for the fire truck. Let me predict that this conceptually confused policy position from the Minister for Employment, Education and Training will in fact never see the light of day.

The second general motivation for this legislation is that the Minister is keen to shore up the support of left wing activists on the campuses in readiness for the forthcoming Federal election. The great majority of student unions in Australia are run by left wingers and, as they control large amounts of compulsorily collected student funds, it is important for the Minister for Employment, Education and Training to have their support. He will need all the support he can find. As an example the National Union of Students, the peak body which represents about 43 of the 68 individual campus unions, will campaign actively for the Labor Party in the forthcoming Federal election, and the Minister for Employment, Education and Training is hopeful that this legislation will prop up his standing with those groups.

Compulsory student unionism was guaranteed by the Whitlam Government in 1973. Student union fees are collected by the university administrations and can amount to $300 per annum per student. In 1989, more than $30m has been collected in compulsory union membership fees. Student unions undertake a number of activities. Firstly, they provide a range of services, including catering, cinemas, child-care, legal aid services, et cetera; secondly, they provide political functions, including the running of newspapers and radio stations, and they provide financial assistance to clubs and societies; thirdly, they act as the representative of students in dealings with university administrations, faculties, departments, et cetera; and, fourthly, they supply the funds for various sporting facilities and organisations on campus.

The proponents of compulsory student unionism claim that universal membership ensures that the unions are representative and that the consequent collective strength gives them the capacity to stand against the unreasonable policy positions of governments and, presumably, of university administrations. These proponents claim that tertiary campuses are like small towns and, therefore, they need certain access to revenue to provide the services which are allegedly of benefit, either directly or indirectly, to all campus members. It is argued that fees are collected from all and then passed on to student unions, with all expenditure being overseen by student representatives elected by the student body. It is argued that, like taxation-this is a favourite analogy made by proponents of compulsory student unionism-this works on the principle that all students benefit from the common pooling of resources. These proponents also claim that on-campus trading operations are sort of inherently unprofitable and that, therefore, if voluntary student unionism was introduced, either services would be reduced or costs would be greatly increased. As I say, that is a favourite scare campaign tactic used by proponents on campuses.

The Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee (AVCC) joins forces with the proponents of compulsory student unionism. University administrators seem very happy to be the bagmen to extract these fees compulsorily and to pass them on to student unions. AVCC members claim that all students benefit from such arrangements and that, therefore, all students should pay. That is an argument that, for example, was put in a submission to the New South Wales Government in August last year and received the endorsement of the University of Sydney, amongst others. The university specifically endorsed the tax analogy argument on the basis that the services provided are essential services from which all benefit in their academic life-an interesting claim, I must say, given the sorts of services that are provided. Unfortunately, the university has not gone on to give us some clarification as to how it might substantiate that rather absurd argument. It supported the extraordinary claim that such bodies provide students `with an avenue for learning management skills and developing qualities of leadership'-which should bring a smile even to the face of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand)-and supported the claim that an administrative nightmare would follow the end of compulsory student unionism. Of course, it failed to explain how catering services could possibly be described as essential or of benefit in academic life and it failed to address one of the difficult arguments for the proponents, that is, whether or not these services are in fact a public good of the type provided by councils, such as roads or garbage collection, as opposed to luxuries, which I would advance are what in fact the major services provided by such organisations are.

The coalition parties object to compulsory student unionism on the ground of principle and on the ground of efficient management. Apart from the important and fundamental objections to compulsory student unionism on the philosophical level, the undemocratic nature of compulsory student unionism contradicts the spirit of free inquiry, association and interaction which should form the heart of all higher education institutions. Compulsory student unionism is an affront to those of us who believe in the concept of freedom of association. Australia is a signatory to a number of international agreements that specifically outlaw compulsory unionism. Let me name three: the United Nations Universal Declaration of Human Rights, the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, and the International Labour Organisation's Convention on the Freedom of Association and the Protection of the Right to Organise. These conventions all support the policy position adopted by the Opposition and we in the Opposition believe that they, in themselves and on their own, represent an unarguable case against compulsory student unionism.

Some will claim-and the AVCC stands with those-that somehow student unionism is different from trade unionism and that this somehow justifies their position. Let me acknowledge that student unions may be different in character, but they are still unions; people are still compulsorily required to subscribe to them.

TALK.START.PARA: —And you hate unions.

—That is a predictable response from someone who is not prepared to go to the basic issues. One of the sad things about the Labor Government is that after seven years it has given up the real policy debate; it has given up the hard tasks of actually arguing for its position. The superficiality of what was said by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs is just a sad, pitiful indictment of the Government of which he is a member.

SPEECH.PARA: Student unions, as with trade unions, which require the compulsory payment of fees are an affront to the concept of freedom of association and, in our view, the principle of freedom of association has an application beyond the industrial movement. The Australian Labor Party likes to claim that the Opposition's dislike of compulsory unionism is somehow translated into opposition against all unionism, as the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs so predictably exhibited just a moment ago. Let me make it quite clear that the Opposition wholeheartedly supports the concept of freedom of association and it totally endorses the right of individuals to establish organisations for political or other reasons. No wonder the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs is so embarrassed. With the pilots dispute, so determined was the Government to make the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) the Ronald Reagan of the Antipodes or the Margaret Thatcher equivalent, it was prepared to dump on a principle on which a few years ago the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, as a left winger with some conscience before the trappings of power got to him, would have stood with the Opposition on the basic question of freedom of association.

TALK.START.PARA: —Stood with you? You'd have to be joking!
—Order! Members should not interject across the table.

—When the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs was just a member of the loony left, at least some people could say, `He might be misguided but at least it is coming from the heart.' However, the reality is that that sort of conscience which he and the other lefties used to have disappeared into the back door of a white limousine. That is a very sad reflection on them. I see the honourable member for Hawker (Mrs Harvey) smiling in acknowledgment of the truth of what I say, and I thank her for that. Being a South Australian member and, given the results of last Saturday's election, as she is about to lose her seat in the next Federal election, I suppose there is no penalty for-
—Order! I ask the honourable member to keep to the debate.
—I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. I ask that the honourable member for Flinders address the Bill rather than give a lesson in history. He should avoid the lecture on European fascism.

—The Opposition supports the right of students to organise and run unions and it supports their right to oppose the policies of any government of the day. We do not object to university unions engaging in political actions. What we do object to is left wing dominated student unions, including the National Union of Students, using compulsorily acquired funds to attack the coalition parties or any parties at election time, especially as these sorts of political attacks are in no way representative of the views of the majority of tertiary students. Of course, many will vote with their feet, as it were; they will vote for us at the next Federal election.

SPEECH.PARA: The coalition does not accept the differences as argued by the AVCC and, not surprisingly, in keeping with our industrial relations policy we will also outlaw compulsory trade unionism. The constant claim of proponents of compulsory student unionism is that their services could not be provided more cheaply or more efficiently by an alternative system. This amounts to a perverse admission that student services are demonstrably inefficient. They say that if the students do not have to pay then no-one will pay, which of course means that what student unions offer is not sufficiently attractive to encourage people to pay voluntarily. When it comes to trade unionism, Bill Kelty himself is constantly recognising that his membership falls because trade unions do not offer what their members are looking for.

Student services suffer from all the same problems of monopolies. Generally student union services have a monopoly in as much as they command a venue on campus which gives them the advantage of location. They have little competition. Who would walk off campus for a cup of coffee when they can get one on campus? Therefore, student union services do not receive any reward for more efficient practices. Their industrial relations record exhibits a tendency to award pace-setting salaries and conditions for the simple reason that they can pass on the additional cost to their captive consumers. Similarly with newspapers, if somebody is running a student newspaper and the union pays a subsidy regardless of the quality of the production, then obviously there is no incentive to do better. Indeed, it becomes incumbent just to churn out leftist propaganda to maintain the subsidy vital to survival.

TALK.START.PARA: —In some places the Right controls them. What happens then?
—I will respond to what the honourable member says.
—The honourable member will not respond to the interjection.
—I will.

—No, the honourable member will not. Order! The honourable member will stick to the contents of the Bill and I ask the honourable member for Perth not to interject. In fact, I ask all honourable members not to interject and I invite the speaker to stick to the contents of the Bill and not to reply to interjections.

—There is little wonder that often university union newspapers are seen blowing in the wind around campuses or sitting in unopened piles awaiting their trip to the tip. The proponents of compulsory student unionism say that the real issue is who should control the delivery of services. Their answer is that it is either the university administration, private enterprise for profit or-their preferred answer-students acting on behalf of all students. Of course, the real answer is none of those. The real answer is that the control of delivery of services should be in the hands of the consumers of the services. The University of Queensland Union is a recent example where it has been shown that huge savings can be made as a result of much more effective administration. In 1989 the new Liberal-National coalition student group turned in a $300,000 profit-a remarkable achievement after only eight or nine months of operation, especially when compared with the $45 profit made by that union in 1988, when it was controlled by the ALP on campus.

SPEECH.PARA: I will respond to the honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth), who referred to newspapers. A similar success story can be found at the Australian National University with the Grunion newspaper. The editors have successfully sold advertising space and are now offering a newspaper that people actually want to read. Instead of being a drain on the general student body, the newspaper runs not only without subsidy but also at a profit. With cafeteria services the fact is that in most urban universities people can walk off the campus to the nearest milk bar and obtain sandwiches and the like for the same price or less than the subsidised product in the university. At the ANU, which is an urban university, privatisation of certain trading facilities, for example, a bakery, newsagent and coffee lounge, has resulted in quality services being offered at competitive prices without the need for a subsidy.

Compulsory student unionism and its attendant service monopolies prohibit competition. Competition provides incentives to maximise efficiencies and allows students the freedom to decide how they spend their own money. Not only are many of these unions notoriously inefficient, but also they have been the vehicles for abuses of the trust placed in student leaders to supervise properly the use of these funds. Funds are provided for a range of clubs and societies, many of which pursue political causes which would be anathema to most students. A recent decision of the Victorian Equal Opportunities Board ruled that Mr Stephen Kenmar, a student who objected to compulsory student unionism, was effectively deprived of his political rights as a result of the political leanings of the Monash Association of Students. Those who support this Bill support that point stated by the Victorian Equal Opportunities Board, that is, the deprivation of political rights. In the 1960s and 1970s the Australian Union of Students took on a number of minority causes. Compulsorily levied funds were used to support the Palestine Liberation Organisation and other terrorist groups. These very unpopular policy decisions helped to bring about the demise of the Australian Union of Students, but this sort of funding continues.

Of course, the National Union of Students will be encouraged by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training to use some of its $600,000 war chest to fund marginal seat campaigns for the Federal ALP in the forthcoming election. This would parallel a decision by the same group to spend $50,000 to campaign against the Liberal- National Party coalition at the last New South Wales State election. Other examples of expenditure to which all students have been obliged to contribute include the following: in 1985, Monash University Students Union, $2,993 for a lesbian and gay men's information and resource booklet; to add injury to insult, in 1986 a further $2,810 for a reprint; $1,761 for a sexuality festival; and $3,200 for Palestinian awareness; in 1986, Melbourne University Students Representative Council, $187 for sexual harassment week, $600 for peace week and $167 for an SRC officer to attend the ALP conference in Hobart; in 1987, $4,065 in conference fares, including the Australian Fabians Conference and conferences against privatisation and tertiary fees; in 1987 Curtin University of Technology, $35,000 for a boycott of the higher education admission charge and $2,000 to the homosexual information office; in 1986, Adelaide University Students Union, $4,000 for a Canberra lobbyist. At the University of Queensland the cost of the subsidies for the radical 4ZZZ was in the vicinity of $110,000 in one year alone. On occasions this radio collective has refused student input. It is using student money but refusing student input. Most of its fanatical supporters are non-student members of the Socialist Workers Party. And members on the Government side support that!

The issue is not whether gays and lesbians on campus, men opposed to patriarchy, the South African Liberation Centre or the Palestinian group are worthy of support. The question those opposite have to answer when they stand is whether or not students should be compulsorily levied to pay for causes which they may not support, or causes to which they are entitled in a democracy to be opposed. Whilst the student unions claim to be representative, it is rare for more than 20 per cent or 25 per cent of the student body actually to vote in student elections. The funds that are made available, and which are collected from the whole of the student body, are concentrated in the hands of a minority, elected by a minority, who are very vocal in defence of their own privileged feather-nested positions as a result of compulsory student unionism.

The coalition's policy is very clear. Unlike the Government, it has a very wide range of policies for the people at the next election-in fact over 30. We will move decisively in this area to legislate for voluntary student unionism. We accept the proposition underlying the Minister's proposal that it is reasonable for the Commonwealth to use the section 96 procedure under the Constitution to require the States to act in a particular way. The Minister proposes that they desist from outlawing compulsory student unionism, whereas by contrast the coalition insists that they introduce voluntary student unionism. One alternative which has been before the coalition is to introduce voluntary student unionism in respect of the political activities of student unions, but to allow the compulsory payment of fees in respect of sporting and welfare activities. We have considered that alternative and I announce that we have come to the view that it is not a viable alternative.

Sporting facilities are important to many students but not all students, particularly part-time and mature age students, would obtain benefits either directly or indirectly from them. Sports clubs ought to be self-financing in the same way as similar amateur clubs outside the campus. Sponsorship for these clubs is an option that should be investigated. Not surprisingly with compulsory fees, those options and the possibilities of raising other revenue outside the university have not been fully exploited.

The cancer of compulsory student unionism must be cut out in full. It would be a futile exercise to remove the more obvious malignancies but leave enough to again threaten the student body. Recent history shows that the proponents of voluntary student unionism must act with complete determination to eradicate this blot on the rights of individuals and this affront to the spirit of free inquiry which should pervade all of our higher education institutions.

In conclusion I pay tribute to the thousands upon thousands of students who have stood up for this basic principle-people such as Robert Clark, John Bell, Julian Sheezel, Sophie Panopolous, Paul Stevenage, Stephen Kenmar, Gerard Wheeler, Brendan Harradine, Darren Olney, Norman Moore, James Duncan, Michael Kroger, Peter Costello, Michael Yabsley and the many others who have resisted compulsion. Their efforts will be rewarded-they will be rewarded shortly after the coalition is returned to the Treasury bench at the forthcoming election early in 1990.

I reiterate that the coalition opposes this Bill. We will oppose with all of our political determination and acknowledged campaigning skills. We look forward to the abolition of this insidious attack on individual rights and we look forward to the introduction of voluntary student unionism in the first half of 1990.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harvey Mrs E.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was a rather disappointing speech from the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith). However, it is not surprising that the quality of his representation of the education portfolio should be so poor because, as we know, the shadow education portfolio comes pretty cheap. This is the portfolio that the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) turned down. He said that he would rather be on the back bench than take it. It is the shadow portfolio that he considered was not important enough and not big deal enough for someone of his undoubted--
—It was beneath him.

—Yes, it was beneath someone of his undoubted integrity and ability. So the shadow education portfolio has ended up in the hands of the honourable member for Flinders and, as a result, we witnessed the quality of the speech he made today. It was typified by the usual knee-jerk, conservative reaction to the mention of the word `union', even in relation to a student union. Whenever they hear those words, members of the Opposition immediately start frothing at the mouth and coming out with all of the old platitudes, and again this is disappointing because I thought that the Opposition had a somewhat more sophisticated and rather more objective view these days about unionism and worker and student representation. It appears, of course, that that is not the case.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Flinders said that the Opposition will fight this Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill tooth and nail. I can assure members of the Opposition that that is something which we on this side of the House look forward to with great relish. The honourable member mentioned that the Bill pandered to what he called the student mates of the Government, the minority ratbag groups and various other insidious elements in universities. As far as I am concerned, and I am sure that my colleagues on this side of the House agree, some of the most insidious groups in the student body in various universities are made up by the members of the various cells of Liberal Youth which seem to flourish in universities and are no doubt behind quite a good deal of the information in the speech delivered today by the honourable member for Flinders.

This Bill in no way legislates for compulsory student unionism. It simply legislates to allow higher education institutions to choose whether or not unionism will be compulsory and to choose how they run their own affairs. That is in no way inconsistent with the general attitude and general policy that this Government has been demonstrating towards higher education institutions. With all of the revolutionary changes that have taken place in higher education policy, it has been uppermost that higher education institutions maintain their autonomy in the running of their internal affairs and particular autonomy in academic freedom.

What we are not allowing universities to do is remain totally unaccountable for their expenditure of taxpayers' funds which we the Government, courtesy of the taxpayers, give them. We are saying that the universities must be efficient and responsible and that they must expend taxpayers' funds responsibly and efficiently and must be accountable for them. We are not in any way interfering with academic freedom, involving courses, or the internal administration of universities.

This Bill is in no way inconsistent with the Government's general policy on higher education. It has been a fundamental thrust of Government policy to guarantee academic freedom and to protect the autonomy of higher education institutions. In particular, the Commonwealth is not prepared to allow State governments to intrude into the legitimate affairs of those institutions and their governing bodies and student organisations. In the last few months there has been evidence of some State government intrusion, particularly in New South Wales and Queensland-and it is not surprising that they are the States we are talking about. They are trying to intrude into internal university matters and, in particular, to abolish compulsory student unionism. Institutions currently impose and collect fees on behalf of student unions. Under the proposed State legislation in New South Wales in particular this would be prohibited.

We know that, of recent years in particular, student unions provide a range of services to the students whom they represent. They provide some very important and very fundamental services. The honourable member for Flinders gave a very selective list of the ways in which student money has been spent but he did not mention the essential counselling services connected with students' academic careers, their careers in general and certain family, social or psychological problems-services that are essential to their welfare and success at university. These are the services that are being provided by student unions using union fees.

There are various other services, such as sporting, health and career services and the necessary social outlets needed by young people in higher education institutions. They are essential and are being provided by student unions; therefore the student unions need all the support they can get. The threatened State government intervention would destroy many of those services and the institutions themselves do not have sufficient resources to offset this loss of fee income for the student unions. The Bill will ensure that the basic rights of institutions to provide for the welfare of their students is not jeopardised by the action being taken by some States to destroy the unions financially.

The measures that we intend to take to ensure that this will be the case are as follows. If a State chooses to legislate in this way-and we cannot stop State governments from doing this-the Commonwealth will provide funding for student unions in the grants to institutions to compensate the unions for any loss of income from union fees. If the Commonwealth is required to compensate unions or institutions in this way, the Commonwealth will recover the cost through an adjustment of the general revenue grants the States receive through the Premiers Conference. These are measures that we are able to take to ensure that the universities and the students in particular do not suffer from this intrusion by the State governments.

The honourable member for Flinders spoke at great length about freedom of association for students. I would like to talk about another freedom which students should have but would not have under a coalition government, and that is the freedom to get to a higher education institution in the first place. What opportunity would young people have for education with the Opposition's proposed $1,200 up-front fee? That is a massive onus to place on students at the beginning of an academic year. It is totally inequitable because the burden would fall most heavily on those students least able to afford it-that is, students from low income families.

Unlike the Opposition's policy, the Government's current system of higher education fees is quite equitable. Last year we introduced the higher education contribution scheme (HECS), otherwise known as the tertiary or graduate tax. At that time, understandably, some legitimate concerns were expressed at what effect it would have on students, particularly on student enrolments. It was suggested that the scheme would be a disincentive for students to take part in higher education. Figures on student enrolments which have come out since then do not bear that out. For example, it was considered that the HECS would lead to falling enrolments, falling commencements, a fall in the number of part time students, particularly female students, and a fall in the number of postgraduate and higher degree students. As it has turned out, that is not the case.

The higher education student population preliminary figure for 1989 is 445,000, which represents an increase of 24,600, or 5.8 per cent, on the 1988 figure. It is the second highest annual growth rate since 1975. Full time enrolments are estimated to be up by 19,800, or 7.8 per cent, in 1989. Part time and external enrolments have risen by 3 per cent and 2.4 per cent respectively. The proportion of female students has increased from 51.1 per cent to 52.1 per cent. In 1989 total commencements are up by 12,300, or 7.3 per cent, and higher degree commencements are up by 17 per cent. This contrasts with the estimate earlier this year of only a one per cent increase in higher degree commencements.

While it now appears that the HECS may have had some impact on external students, the system as a whole has experienced substantial growth. Full time student numbers in particular have maintained their rapid rate of increase. Both higher degree and undergraduate numbers are up significantly. Later in the year the Government will have more detailed and accurate figures. One can see that the predictions of the opponents of HECS that enrolments and commencements would fall drastically this year as a result of some alleged disincentive have not been fulfilled.

I repeat the reasons that we introduced the higher education contribution scheme. Up until now there were not enough places in tertiary education institutions for those who needed them. In the 1980s there has not been the evidence that young people from lower income families and state schools are entering universities in the proportion that they should. The money acquired from the higher education contribution scheme will be used to fund more places so that more young people will be able to get into tertiary institutions. It will also enable us to pay more by way of Austudy. We will be able to extend the eligibility for Austudy and increase the rates of Austudy, which is of inestimable value to secondary students who are coming up to the tertiary education years and to lower income tertiary students who need income support while they are studying.

I repeat that the Opposition's policy of a $1,200 fee paid up-front every year would be a massive burden on the students I have been talking about. The honourable member for Flinders talked about the freedom of students to associate. I say to him: what about the freedom of young people to enter a tertiary institution in the first place? That freedom, that opportunity, that they have under us with the assistance that we provide would not exist under a coalition government when a massive $1,200 fee would have to be paid up-front. The Opposition talks about having scholarships for 25 per cent of students. That means that we would revert to the old system in the pre-Whitlam days when to get to university a person had to be either rich or good at passing exams. I think everybody agreed that that was not an equitable system. The present system gives all students an equal opportunity to enter a tertiary institution. What we say is that afterwards, when they graduate and are earning a reasonable salary, they should pay back over a number of years one-fifth of the cost of their tertiary education. I do not believe that that is an unreasonable measure to take.

I fully support the Bill which legislates to prevent State governments intruding into the internal affairs of tertiary institutions, particularly the way in which they organise their student unions. I look forward, as do my colleagues, to watching the Opposition fighting the Bill tooth and nail, as the honourable member for Flinders said. I look forward to hearing what the Opposition's next speaker presents to us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Despite the understanding-if that is the right word-of the honourable member for Hawker (Mrs Harvey), the apparently innocuous title of this Bill belies what is in fact a very important and utterly disgraceful attempt by the Federal Government to deny students freedom of association while attending tertiary institutions. The Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 3) seeks to use Federal financial powers under section 96 of the Constitution to prevent State governments from legislating to ensure that membership of student unions and associations is truly voluntary. Although the Bill might be seen as an abuse of Commonwealth power, it is not the matter of so-called States rights which is at issue but the freedom for individual students to choose to join, or not to join, student associations. The Bill seeks to deny those rights on entirely spurious grounds.

SPEECH.PARA: The Labor Government is abusing the power of the Parliament to reward and further the interests of its own political supporters at the expense of the liberty of all and, in particular, the freedom of those students who have no desire to be involved in political games which are an integral part of student unions. At present in this country the right to freedom of association is effectively denied to many Australians through both industrial law and practices and compulsory membership of student associations. These abuses are clearly in contravention of such widely accepted accounts of human rights as the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, which in Article 20 states:
Everyone has the right to freedom of peaceful assembly and association.
No-one may be compelled to belong to an association.

Australia is a signatory to that declaration. Industrial law imposes compulsion through the practice of the closed shop and through preference clauses in industrial relations Acts which deny employment to people who wish to choose not to join a union.

The system of registration of trade unions and employer groups also denies the freedom to form an association to those in the industrial arena. I have spoken about these issues in the House previously, only to hear a response from members opposite which either denies in the face of all evidence to the contrary the reality of forced membership or seeks to justify such an abhorrent practice by reference to euphemistic industrial relations realities. These so-called realities have condemned this country to declining industry, declining standards of living, and the economic mess we face after too many years of Labor rule.

The position with student associations is an even more blatant denial of the essential liberty of freedom of association. State government legislation which establishes tertiary institutions and Federal Government legislation for institutions in the Territories enforce compulsory membership of student associations through both forced membership and coerced fees collected on behalf of the student associations. The Federal Government does not have direct constitutional power to legislate for the establishment of universities in the States and their structures. However, this legislation will use Federal financial powers to prevent State governments implementing legislation, if they are of a mind at any time in the future to remove the compulsory membership of student associations. Indeed, the mechanism of this proposed legislation is curious. It involves quite extraordinary incentives for student unions to seek and gain government funding while granting the Minister for Employment, Education and Training unusual and excessive discretionary powers in determining the application of this legislation.

The Bill is envisaged as a pre-emptive strike against State governments which might consider the introduction of legislation to guarantee freedom of association in tertiary institutions. The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Simmons), on behalf of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins), in his second reading speech said that he hopes that this Bill will intimidate State Ministers sufficiently to ensure that `the provisions of this Bill will never need to be invoked'. If they are invoked, then the legislation will require State governments to pay student unions an amount to be determined by the Federal Minister to make up for the loss in revenue from students choosing not to join the association concerned. This is an extraordinary way of going about what is really a rather tawdry exercise in coercing students. This Bill allows the Minister unlimited discretion to determine the amount by which student associations will be compensated. It will effectively reward the most incompetent student unions, which will lose the largest number of members if membership becomes voluntary.

The Bill will deny students the economic benefits of voluntary membership by removing the incentives of greater efficiency and better service from student unions. If this Bill comes into effect, far from providing a guarantee of institutional autonomy, it will make student unions a dependent client of the Federal Minister. The Minister is already bowing down to the vested interests of the few who gain from their participation in student associations at the expense of the many who have other priorities when they study at university.

For a very short Bill, this piece of legislation is an example of many of the worst features of government decisions under Labor, such as pandering to vested interests, extending ministerial discretion to avoid parliamentary scrutiny, economic irrationality, abuse of Commonwealth powers, and trampling on the rights and freedoms of individuals. For these reasons, I suggest that the Bill is fundamentally flawed and should be rejected, no matter what members think of the principles behind the Bill. However, those principles are important, and I will go on to discuss them in some detail before refuting some of the most common myths about student unions and the provision of services for students. Freedom of association cannot be a conditional freedom, to be granted by permission of the Government and denied if that permission is not forthcoming. However, that is the form of limited freedom which exists for so many today in Australia.

The Commonwealth Government has established privileged private associations and adds to frequent government subsidy and patronage by granting them monopoly rights in their fields. There is only one official representative of students on campuses, just as there is only one major registered union in most industries in Australia and only one official political party in less democratic countries than ours. Liberty to join or not to join these associations cannot be conditional upon the acceptance of that association, as it is under most schemes for so-called conscientious objection in Australia. True freedom of association should surely be a simple matter of choice. The question `Would you like to join?', answered `Yes' or `No', is the essence of that freedom. The ability to avoid otherwise compulsory membership is not the same as the liberty to choose membership, which all Australians should have. Australian students at tertiary institutions do not have that liberty. The payment of fees to student associations is a precondition of enrolment at universities across the country. If the fee is not paid, then the opportunity for higher education is denied. The fee does not pay for a student's education or for essential services provided by the university, but pays for a range of services, facilities and subsidies to other students which are by no means necessary for an education.

Virtually all the functions performed by student unions can be provided privately on a fee-for-service basis. Many facilities, such as catering, are provided already near the campuses at a higher quality and more competitive price by private traders. Compulsory union fees have allowed student associations to become an inefficient burden on the lives of many students. The existence of subsidy through the fee makes the trading operations of the student associations inefficient and leads to the provision of services which are desired by few, if any. It has already led to the politicising of these associations as one gang or another seeks to control the resources of the student unions.

The provision for conscientious objection at some universities, which is opposed by most Labor governments in any case, changes none of this. In most cases the students must pay their money to a charity or some other group instead of the union. In other cases the money is paid to the student association by the university, regardless of whether the student is a member. This is not a substitute for freedom of association, but rather a form of fine for those who do not want to be members of student associations. Conscientious objection is a perversion of free association. It represents a concession to vested interests which, while apparently innocuous, is a running sore on the face of Australian democracy. Many members opposite took pride in their stance against conscription to fight in the Vietnam War. They claimed then that conscientious objection did not reduce the evil of conscription. However, when their own and their supporters' interests are challenged, they are quite willing to entrench the conscription of students as members of student unions, using the feeble defence that conscientious objection caters for the dissenters.

Despite the rationalising by university administrators defending their acquiescence in the forcing of students to pay fees to the student unions, the fee is not primarily a fee for services and amenities but is a compulsory fee collected for the benefit of a student union which happens to provide some services and amenities. All of these services can and should be provided on a user pays basis. Students should not be forced to pay for the leisure of other students or to fund a political training ground for those who have come to dominate the student unions.

On top of this, students are also likely to be paying for their affiliation with a national student union and a range of other organisations with which their campus student union is involved. I am sure that many members are aware of the abuses of student funds, which have become legion under the regime of compulsory membership of student unions. Donations to the Palestine Liberation Organisation and other terrorist organisations, as well as support for numerous extremist causes which are not relevant to most students, have been well documented by a source as credible as the Australian Labor Party candidate for Goldstein, Mr Michael Danby, who has written:

Why the establishment seemed so unwilling to permit freedom of association for students, either on individual campuses or nationally (and the one necessarily implied the other), remains a mystery to many . . .

Mr Danby's principled position is an indication that this is certainly not a partisan issue. The students who find compulsion most distasteful are usually those who dislike politics in general, regardless of whether it is a product of the Liberal Party or the Labor Party and their supporters. The defence of compulsion is usually clothed in arguments which barely cover the naked self-interest of those promoting them. The first of these myths is that because of the free rider problem all students should be forced to contribute equally to the student union. In fact, the free riders are those involved in so-called student politics and those who make extensive use of a union's facilities. Their activities are at present largely dependent on the forced contributions of those who do not wish to use those facilities.

We all benefit from the voluntary actions of some private associations and are all damaged by the activities of others. But we are not forced to make contributions to, for example, the various automobile associations, despite the benefits which they provide for all road users. Nor are those who do not join a private association in any meaningful sense free riders when that association can easily ensure that the benefits of the association are restricted to members.

In his second reading speech, the Minister lists a number of services which student unions provide. It is a somewhat idealised list of what is important in the operations of student unions, but none of the functions which he lists, and no conceivable functions, would justify forced membership and forced contributions. We can dismiss the free rider fallacy.

Another defence of compulsion is the assertion that a student union is like a government and therefore should be compulsory. It is not. The very suggestion that some students should have the right to govern others is both ridiculous and offensive.

The President of the National Union of Students has argued that the issue of voluntary membership is secondary to the question of who should control student services. Apart from the incorrect assumption that someone must control a monopoly on those services, that argument assumes that there is so little demand for the services which student unions provide that they would not exist if they were not forced on students. A number of studies make it quite clear that the provision of most services for students on campuses can be funded on a user pays basis or through the private sector.

The defence of compulsion, which is necessary to justify this legislation, ultimately rests on the assertion that Australian university students are not able to make independent decisions about how to look after themselves and how to spend their own money. It asserts that some students should be placed in a privileged position in relation to that of their colleagues, having the government-granted right to force other students to join their association. However, compulsion is unjustified.

Why then is there no attempt to justify this abuse of power by the Commonwealth Government in this legislation? The answer is that the Minister has chosen to use surreptitious and dishonest means to achieve his end. He argues that for a State government to legislate for guarantees of freedom of association for students is to interfere in the autonomy of higher education institutions. One could be forgiven for thinking that this argument is just a sick joke from the Minister who, more than any other Federal Minister, has made universities a creature of his whim and his Department.

Universities do not have the autonomy to infringe the rights and freedoms of their students. At present compulsion is enforced through provisions in government legislation which establishes those institutions. If genuine autonomy is granted to those institutions within the rule of law, and in accordance with the general principles which should apply to all citizens, then compulsory membership of student unions could not continue.

The Federal Government does not have the constitutional power directly to enforce compulsory membership of student unions. However, it is willing to do whatever it can to uphold this abhorrent practice through this legislation. To conclude, I would like to quote a past student who has written:

Compulsory student unionism provides the vast majority of students with few, if any, benefits. It works upon a political model to which many students are opposed, and helps unrepresentative extremists. It can not be justified in theory or practice and does nothing but harm. It is unethical. It damages the whole concept of democratic society, especially because the group it affects, that is, university students, tends to pass into influential positions in the community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brumby Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 3). I have been present during the debate here and have listened to Opposition speakers today. I think there may be some element of misunderstanding or confusion about the intent and nature of this legislation before the House. Put very simply, the legislation is about reducing, diminishing, government control over institutions. It is very much aimed at providing institutions themselves with the autonomy and right to make their own decisions in relation to these matters.

SPEECH.PARA: The remarks of Opposition speakers here today represent something of a paradox. Their rhetoric on autonomy, freedom of speech and economic issues like deregulation is very strong indeed but when it comes to the crunch one would have to describe them as the great pretenders. In their contributions to the debate they said that they want and support the heavy hand of government interference-in this case, State government interference-to determine which institutions can or cannot raise money from students for the legitimate purpose of providing services for those students. That is what members of the Opposition have said in this debate today. There should not be any mistake about it. Basically members of the Opposition have said that they support, in this particular instance, the New South Wales State Government in broad brush legislation proscribing certain activities by higher education institutions.

What the Commonwealth Labor Government is saying is totally consistent with everything that we have done in higher education since being elected in 1983. We are saying that the decisions about student fees, student unions and student associations should be decisions for the institutions themselves to make. The Opposition's rhetoric on all of these liberal values-autonomy, free speech, deregulation, letting the people decide-is strong but today it is fundamentally asserting that it supports the heavy hand of government interference, prescribing and proscribing what can and cannot be done by institutions in a particular State in Australia.

What the Government is laying down in this legislation is very simple. Unlike what was alleged by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher), there is no devious intent; it is a very simple, straightforward piece of legislation. We are providing the right for institutions themselves to determine whether a student union fee should be raised.

The previous speaker spoke at some length about the purposes for which student union fees can or cannot be used. But the fact is that those fees provide a very wide range of services for students. In all likelihood those services would simply not be available if those fees were not raised because institutions do not have buckets full of money sitting around in academic theatres and in lecture rooms waiting to be spent. They do not have unlimited access to financial resources.

If those fees were not available a range of services, such as counselling services, sporting facilities, health services, assistance with accommodation and emergency accommodation for students in need and career services would not be available. A range of services which provide necessary social outlets for young people are provided in institutions. I repeat: if the legislation which is being proposed by one State government-I might say by only one State government-is passed and those institutions do not have the capacity to raise those resources, students will be denied a range of services which are important to their ongoing success and achievement in higher education. This Bill is about protecting the basic rights of institutions. It ensures that institutions will be able to provide for the welfare of their students. It will ensure that their autonomy is not jeopardised by the heavy-handed actions of State governments with an ideological agenda.

This Bill touches on other issues of great importance to education and higher education. In an earlier contribution today, the honourable member for Hawker (Mrs Harvey) explained some of those issues extremely well and extremely succinctly. This Government has a record of which it can be rightly proud in higher education. Recent statistics released about higher education confirm the success of this Government's policies. For instance, this year the number of students starting higher education degrees-that is, masters and doctorate courses-in Australian universities and colleges increased by 17 per cent. So much for the claims often made by Opposition members about the serious problems relating to higher degrees and research in Australia. The fact is that this year there is a 17 per cent increase in the number of students starting higher degrees.

In the total higher education sector there are also statistics which totally debunk the claims that the higher education contribution scheme introduced by this Government has turned students away from enrolling in universities and colleges. This year about 445,000 students enrolled in Australian higher education courses-that is an increase of about 25,000 students or 6 per cent on last year's figure. It is the second highest growth rate in 15 years-since 1975. Full time enrolments are up by 8 per cent. Part time and external enrolments are up by 3 per cent and female enrolments have also increased. The recent funding that the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins), who is in the chamber listening to this debate, has announced for the next triennium-1989 to 1991-will ensure that there is funding for an additional 49,000 places. That will ensure further healthy increases in enrolments in the years to come.

The honourable member for Hawker in her contribution mentioned the Opposition's policy in relation to higher education. She referred to the Opposition's Economic Action Plan policy to introduce a $1,200 up-front fee for any student wanting to participate in higher education. It is somewhat ironic to hear Opposition members in this debate talk about the so-called rights of students to participate in student union activity and to contribute financially to those activities when, under its recently announced Economic Action Plan, a large number of students simply will not have the opportunity to participate in higher education because of the $1,200 up-front fee. Let me go back through these statistics.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you read the details of it?

—The honourable member for Lowe will have his opportunity in a moment to justify the $1,200 up-front fee. He can justify it in this House. He can justify it to the students in his electorate of Lowe and he can tell people from working class families that if they want to go on to higher education his Government will charge them $1,200 up-front; not to be paid later; not means tested and not income tested. That is what the Opposition says in its policy.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government has been honest enough to say that it believes students should contribute to higher education. We had the political courage to make a decision to introduce the higher education administration charge some years ago. That was a $250 charge. It was an up-front fee. We have now replaced that with the higher education contribution scheme. One of the reasons we replaced the higher education administration charge-HEAC, the $250 up-front charge-with the contribution scheme, which is an income tested, pay later scheme, was that there was evidence that students were turning away from higher education because they had to pay that modest amount of $250. There was evidence that this was occurring amongst the very people that I am sure all of us in this Parliament would want to see participating in higher education-people who have not had the opportunity before, people from low income families. Even with a fee of $250 there was evidence that people were being turned away and discouraged from continuing on to higher education. So we abolished that charge and we introduced the contribution scheme, which is an income tested, pay later scheme. No-one is forced to pay up- front. People do not repay a cent under that contribution scheme until their income exceeds a certain level in the future-about the figure of average weekly earnings.

If one looks at the statistics which I have explained and tabled in this House today on higher education growth since we introduced the contribution scheme one sees that the number of people starting masters and doctorate courses is up by 17 per cent this year. We have never had increases of that dimension before. Despite the higher education contribution fee, regular full time enrolments in higher education are up by 8 per cent this year. Perhaps `despite' is not the right word, because we should never forget that every cent and dollar raised from the higher education contribution scheme goes back into funding more places in higher education. It goes back to provide new opportunities for the 49,000 extra places that will be available to young Australians over the next triennium.

I believe that, if the Opposition's $1,200 proposal is ever introduced, it will be the biggest single disincentive that has ever been put in place and that it will limit young people's access to higher education in Australia. I represent a provincial electorate based on Bendigo and the towns of Maryborough, St Arnaud, Charlton and Wedderburn, in other words, a large number of rural people. If they send their child to college or university, invariably the child must live away from home. Despite the large increases made by this Government to Austudy, the fact is that, if parents lives in the bush and send their child to college or university in Melbourne, they can expect to pay between $5,000 and $10,000 per annum to assist and support that child. Even if they are undertaking some part time work or have some Austudy allowance, that is about what it costs a parent to send a child to university or college in Melbourne.

The Government wants to increase that $5,000 to $6,200. It wants $1,200 to be put up-front, which is a further impost on these children from the bush who want to participate in higher education. The statistics demonstrate that, when this Government was elected, young people from the bush were three times less likely to participate in higher education than their city cousins. We have put in place a range of programs to improve the prospects of those children. I am pleased to say that we are improving the prospects of young people from country areas. But it is absolute lunacy to suggest that an opposition party with a rural rump, the National Party, should support a policy to impose on young country people around Australia a $1,200 up-front fee.

This Government has an outstanding record in education and I want to acknowledge the outstanding contributions made in that regard by the current Minister for Employment, Education and Training and his predecessor, Senator Susan Ryan. Under this Government, in the schools area the retention rate has increased from 36 per cent to more than 60 per cent. As the Minister noted yesterday during Question time, when we were elected in 1983 the number of apprenticeship positions was 35,000, but that number has been increased to more than 60,000 this year, so we have almost doubled the number of apprenticeship positions for young people. We introduced the traineeship scheme and the number of traineeships in Australia now amounts to 17,000. With that figure and the increased number of apprentices, about 45,000 more young people now enjoy training opportunities through apprenticeship or traineeship programs.

In 1983 we had 350,000 students in higher education in Australia, and this year that number will have increased to 450,000, which is an increase of 100,000 students. To put that increase in perspective, that is equivalent to building about 30 new colleges of advanced education of the size of the Bendigo College of Advanced Education. In seven years we have built 30 new colleges to accommodate 100,000 extra students. We have dramatically increased Austudy. When we were elected 53,000 young people received benefits from that scheme, but that figure has now increased to 142,000. The number of students in higher education has increased from 96,000 to 140,000. In terms of youth unemployment, as a proportion of teenage population, we have reduced that figure to about 6.5 per cent, which is similar to the ratio for the community as a whole.

I support this legislation and our ongoing program of reform in higher education. I commend to this House and to the Australian people the wide range of initiatives we have put in place to provide education opportunities for young people.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Bendigo also made some amazing statements about autonomy. TALK.START.PARA: —That is fair.

—The honourable member wants the taxpayers to support the compulsory unionism of these universities. SPEECH.PARA: Most students in most universities are forced to pay-`forced' is exactly the right word-up to $300 to join a union, in many cases the facilities of which they do not use and the political views of which they do not share. It is a bizarre but classic example of how the ALP sees democracy, a democracy that does not involve any freedom of choice.

As has been pointed out already, student unions have been known to contribute to a number of radical causes, which they have the right to do if it is with the wishes of the majority, but the vast majority of the causes to which they contribute-without going into an exhaustive list, I will name some of them in a minute-are not representative of the interests of the majority of students. In his second reading speech, the Minister sought to justify the Bill by stating that it is an important measure in the Government's efforts to protect the legitimate autonomy of higher education institutions.
