With this Bill the ALP is doing no more than ensuring that at the forthcoming election it can count on the taxpayer and the students, who may have no political direction but who are obliged to pay union fees to get into university, to underwrite the ALP campaign, regardless of the views of those students.

There is no doubt that the Bill is a fundamental denial of the right of freedom of association which all Australians should have to determine whether they wish to belong to a student union. The Bill continues the blatant abuse and misuse of students' funds. Compulsory unionism stifles competition while union monopoly in most cases limits choice. It means that things like university shops can charge more for an inferior service. In October this year a lockout was imposed on Sydney University's 160,000 students, which shows how unions can act contrary to the wishes of their members. The union employees barricaded eating areas, closed union run shops, shut down sporting facilities and issued union propaganda in the form of banners, posters and leaflets, all paid for out of members' funds. It was done supposedly to reprimand those in favour of the principle of voluntary unionism.

The situation is, as in most other bureaucratised areas, that such control means that prices are higher. There is less competition. People cannot go off campus. They cannot go to alternative free enterprise operations. It basically means that in that protected environment the services offered are expensive and inefficient. When student unions have established a businesslike footing rather than just a left wing benevolent fund, enormous savings have been made to the benefit of all the students.

Some honourable members opposite have said that they believe that unions should be treated as if they were small towns and that student unions are like local governments or local councils. The difficulty is that most governments and most councils provide the important needs of residents. We are talking here in the universities in many cases of luxuries. We are not talking about the basic requirements of being a student. Surely university sports clubs, for example, should be self-financing, as in the rest of the community. It seems amazing to me also that the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee should support the concept of compulsion. This, after all, is the body which is constantly, and rightly, complaining about the Minister's interference in freedom in academia.

There was an interesting case in Victoria this year, that of Kenmar v. Monash University in front of the Equal Opportunities Board. It was essentially a dispute over the right of a student to refuse to pay the student union levy because he did not believe the union represented his rights. Because joining the union was a prerequisite of his study there, he was threatened with disenrolment. Clearly, that decision was a denial of the student's right of freedom of association. The Equal Opportunity Act in Victoria states that people cannot be discriminated against for their political beliefs. While the case went against him in the end, the Board found that the Monash Association of Students engaged in political activities and that, because these activities were different from the student's own beliefs, he was treated less favourably than other students. Although he lost the case, this point vindicates the argument for voluntary unionism.

In the eyes of many commentators, unfortunately, many university administrators have been forced to become bagmen for the unions. While compulsory unionism must nag at their consciences, they are forced to accept it because without union funds they would be unable to fund the services that the unions provide, unless they were accepted by the vast majority of students. Peter Costello put it this way:

Although universities jealously guard their independence, their rights to free inquiry, and their rights to free speech, it seems they are all too willing to compromise their student's rights to freedom of association . . . the double standards of university administrators, who insist on, or at least acquiesce in, the conscription of students into university unions, guilds and student associations.
He continues:

It is interesting that student leaders have no qualms about the compulsory collection of levies which they spend, but are strongly opposed to government attempts to recoup some of the funds taxpayers spend on providing `free' tertiary education. The campaign against the Higher Education Administration charge illustrates again how the voice of the select group which stands to gain is much louder than the diffuse group at whose expense the gain is made.
I also point out a few of the gross inconsistencies of the ALP in regard to freedom of association. Article 20 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights states:
No-one may be compelled to belong to an association.
Article 2 of the International Labor Organisation Convention Concerning Freedom of Association and Protection of the Right to Organise states:

Workers and employers, without distinction whatsoever, shall have the right to establish and, subject only to the rules of the organisation concerned, to join organisations of their own choosing without previous authorisation.
Article 22 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, the ICCPR, states:
Everyone shall have the right to freedom of association with others . . .

Australia, the Government, is a signatory to those conventions. The coalition position is spelt out very clearly in our higher education policy. We do not support compulsory student unionism or, indeed, any other compulsory unionism. Apart from fundamental objections to it on a philosophical level, we also feel that the undemocratic nature of compulsory student unionism contradicts the spirit of free inquiry, association and interaction which should form the heart of all higher education institutions. The next Liberal-National Government will ensure that compulsory student unionship is not forced on students in higher education institutions which constitutionally are the full responsibility of the Commonwealth. We will also require the States as a condition of funding to ensure that compulsory student unionism is not forced on students in their higher education institutions.

The Labor changes which have occurred over the last year or so for spurious reasons-the Government has said that the economy needs changes in the universities; the economy does need changes, although it has nothing to do with the universities but is due to the incompetence of the Government-have resulted in more centralisation, more amalgamation, more government control and intervention in direct research, towards a so-called national priority. We would support entirely the merit of freedom in research, research done for its own sake, pure research.

The academic freedom of our universities is of overwhelming importance to those institutions. We would restore control to our institutions. We would encourage healthy competition. We would continue expansion. The fact that the Minister himself has been espousing a charter for academic freedom is indeed surely a de facto admission that in fact there are problems in terms of the freedoms of universities as a result of the Government's interventions and centralisation of control in the tertiary education sphere and, increasingly, also in the secondary education sphere over the last year or so. The comments by Professor Penington in regard to this matter were entirely appropriate. He basically said that the charter for academic freedom, for example, would have little meaning when the political control and the political control mechanisms are still in place, as they are under this Government.

Together the Liberals and Nationals in the future will dismantle the unified system and abolish those dreaded education profiles, the means by which centralisation of control is transferred to the Federal Government. We would encourage disamalgamation. We would allow the freedom of the institutions to specialise in particular areas free from centralised control, free from the heavy hand of the Federal Government in regard to these matters. We would also make sure that we modified the guidelines for the Australian Research Council.

It comes back to the same issue again and again: freedom of academia is of vital importance. Government control of the direction of research, as occurs in all the Iron Curtain countries, does not lead to an improvement in our understanding or knowledge of the world about us. It does not, indeed, even allow for an improvement in the technology of the country and its contribution to our society or to our economy, which is in such dreadful need of a boost as a result of the heavy hand of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the so-called world's greatest Treasurer (Mr Keating). The economy is in a sorry state, but, by interfering in educational profiles and in the independence of educational institutions, we are not going to improve that. Those issues are separate and relate to the reform of trade union practices, encouraging incentive and privatisation of a number of institutions to allow for freedom, competition and increased productivity. In the long run an educational program is an important part of that. The intervention of the Government, however, in these educational matters and the centralisation of control within the Minister's own portfolio and within his own office will do nothing to increase the benefits to the community as a whole. It will increase only the Minister's power.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charlesworth Dr R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Lowe (Dr Woods), as perhaps we should expect in this place, muttered some trite and simplistic suggestions, but the principal premise of his argument is that we should come to this place and argue consistency. He said that there was no consistency in the provisions of this legislation and that indeed it was hypocritical of the Government to take this position. I believe he was being hypocritical. The people who live in the electorate of Lowe should understand very clearly that he strongly supports the principle that, before a person has access to tertiary education in this country, he has to have $1,200 or else he cannot even get in the door. The point we in the Government have made very clearly again and again when we debate education in this place is that we believe there should be no impediment to those who wish to pursue tertiary education, if they qualify through the school system. Indeed, it is important for us to understand that there should be no impediment to their being able to pursue a tertiary study course. The Opposition's policy, announced in the Economic Action Plan, is that there will be such an impediment-$1,200. For many of the working class families who live in Lowe, that will be too much for them and will preclude them from the system.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition argues for consistency in this area. I agree that some of the things said by the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) are superficially attractive. He talked about individual rights and freedom of association and freedom to choose, but the choice that has to be made by students when they leave the school system is whether or not they will pursue a tertiary course. Once they choose to take that course then, just as those of us in this Government and in Australia choose to abide by the laws and rules laid down by the Government, so must those students. It is not the Federal Government that is imposing these fees; it is a State government that is trying to interfere with the right and autonomy of institutions to say that students should have a say, should be represented and have a presence in the running of their organisations and institutions.

It is a perfectly reasonable proposition that students should have a say. In order to do so, it is expected that there will be automatic membership of the student body. If students, once they become members of the student body, choose not to exercise their right to vote in elections for the student body and not to use the facilities and services provided, that remains their choice and they are not in any way disadvantaged by making that choice. But the choice they make to be part of the institution is one they make consciously. Once they do that they have to fall within the rules and requirements of the institutions-not of this Government or the State government but the institution. The Government is providing for the autonomy of the institution. It is the vice-chancellors of those institutions who believe that students need to have a say and should have a body to represent them and provide services and facilities. We are defending the right of the institutions to make that decision and to determine that.

I understand that it is the Federal Opposition's policy that taxation in this country should be voluntary. God knows, for long enough when it was in government taxation was voluntary for many. By the same argument of consistency the Opposition put earlier, we could argue that childless couples should not have any of their tax made available for child-care, that people who do not have cars should not have any of the tax they pay made available for road maintenance, and that a working taxpayer like me should not have any of his taxation money made available for pensions. I could go on and on. If I do not have any children, why should I be paying for the education of other people's children? If the Opposition wants to argue consistency, it has to argue that, but it does not do that. Opposition speakers take a cheap point because the State Government in New South Wales is trying to make some political mileage.

What we are doing is protecting the autonomy of the organisations and the institutions that provide for higher education. If Opposition members want to argue consistency, they should be consistent. They should not come here and carry on as they have. What the Government is defending is the right of student bodies to be represented on campus. They are constituted democratically; they have elections; all the students have a say and have the right to vote. If some choose not to, that is their right too, just as at the next Federal election people have the right to vote informal. It is humbug for the Opposition to come here and to argue as it does on this issue. In doing so, it is not being consistent.

The honourable member for Flinders said that what the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) is about is providing for minority, ratbag groups, left wing activists. What the honourable member for Flinders should do is go to the University of Western Australia, where I was a student some time ago, and where indeed the Minister was a student in days gone by-and an outstanding student at that, I might say. What happened at the University of Western Australia is that from time to time the student body was controlled by different groups. Sometimes it was the Labor faction or the socialist faction, sometimes it was the conservative faction. Whenever it was the left wing, or the Labor faction, whatever one wants to call it, the conservative faction was always saying that there should not be compulsory membership. It was trying to tear it down, in the same way as the Opposition comes into this place and tries to tear down Australia's economy. It does that because it suits its purposes. But what do we find now? From 1987 to 1989 the control of the guild in the University of Western Australia has been under the auspices of the Liberal group, and there has been not a whimper about this issue. It is the Liberals who are inconsistent and it is their humbug that we are seeing in this debate. When they are in control there is not a whimper about compulsory membership, but as soon as they are out of power they are all complaining.

The honourable member for Flinders said that student unions are not efficient. If they are not efficient, I do not support them, either. They should not be inefficient. The Government is not suggesting that they should be inefficient; it is saying that, with the dollars they raise and for the way in which they spend their money, they should be very efficient. If the honourable member is suggesting for a moment that the Government in some way is legislating for or suggesting that it supports inefficiency in those student bodies, I say to him that that is not the case. Certainly we suggest that they should be efficient. Indeed, if they are not, there needs to be management change, and within the democratic process that exists amongst those student bodies it is possible for members of the guild or union or whatever one wants to call it-it varies from place to place-to argue their case as to the way in which changes should be made, or indeed to change the leadership of the union. So it is possible within the democratic process in student unions to do that.

The honourable member for Flinders suggested that the Australian Union of Students had for a long time pursued a very marginal agenda, that it had supported the Palestine Liberation Organisation and various other groups and that, as a result, it had fallen on tough times and that that had led to its demise. All he is doing in saying that is arguing the case that these organisations are democratic and that, if they pursue an agenda which is inappropriate for the mainstream members of the organisation, they will fall on bad times and it will bring about their own demise. Indeed, his point underpins the democracy of the way in which these organisations are constituted. He made a further grubby point, but I believe it needs to be followed up, that in fact one organisation had spent a couple of thousand dollars on producing a homosexuality pamphlet for students. I do not know what he was trying to get at. Perhaps he was trying to play on a very sensitive nerve in public opinion, but he needs to understand that 10 per cent of the population is homosexual and probably 10 per cent of students are homosexual. Therefore spending a couple of thousand dollars out of a budget of millions of dollars on that pamphlet, which provides information for 10 per cent of the student body, is a reasonable thing. The honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) said in this House that the right to conscientiously object against student union membership was on the same level as the right to conscientiously object against that despicable, or certainly unconstitutional or inappropriate, conscription legislation which was introduced during the Vietnam war. I do not believe that the order of magnitude of the two things is the same. We are talking about being asked to defend one's country and to lay down one's life for a cause that one does not support, which is an issue quite different from whether or not one should conscientiously object to student union membership. If the Opposition wants to argue consistency, it should be arguing in this House against seat belt legislation. If that is the way the Opposition wants to argue, people should not be made to wear seat belts. If the Opposition believes that the order of magnitude of these two things is the same, that is the way it should be doing it. However, it does not argue that case and that needs to be understood very well.

People must understand what being a student involves. It is something that entails a great deal of application to the task ahead. Some courses have a great many contact hours and some have many fewer, but the facilities provided on campus are very important for those students who have a great number of contact hours. For instance, when I was pursuing my course we had four lectures in the morning and a practical lesson in the afternoon. If we were lucky we had 50 minutes for lunch in the middle. We did not have the opportunity to rush down to the shop and order lunch; instead, a very good meal was provided on campus for us at a better rate than anywhere else. There was no question about that, and it is still the case. Those facilities are important.

Honourable members have mentioned that it is just unfair-and I have already answered this assertion-that those services and facilities provided by the students and the student bodies are not available to everybody. I suggest that they look at a particular example, such as the University of Western Australia. The 32 different sporting clubs in that university have 2,600 members, nearly 20 per cent of the student body. That is a significant proportion of the student body who, because of their union membership, have some advantages. The Opposition might say that that is unfair, but that university has another program called the Recreate program which has between 90 and 100 courses in languages, photography, car and bike care, arts, crafts-you name it-and more than 7,000 students take part in those courses. Additionally, they have counselling facilities available. These counselling facilities are not provided by the institution, with which the students may have conflict; it is independent counselling representing students. The university has education officers and provides catering services and independent advice. It has a housing officer who provides assistance to students who need rental property close to the university. They provide a myriad of important services that students need. There is a gymnasium and health club with 1,500 members. This is not some marginalised group that is benefiting. There are 7,000 members in the Recreate program, 2,500 in sporting clubs and 1,500 involved in the health club. Indeed, the whole student body is benefiting from student union membership and the program that it puts in place.

—I refer the Treasurer to today's national accounts for the September quarter, which suggest that gross national expenditure did not rise despite the significant increases in government and private consumption expenditure and business investment expenditure. —My question is directed to the Minister for Housing and Aged Care. The PBRT has already made that abundantly clear in its statement of 17 November. The Commonwealth believes that, if an inquiry were to proceed, the terms of reference and methodology should be open to discussion in front of the PBRT.

ANSWER.PARA: In the meantime, the Commonwealth has put to the PBRT today that, in the course of any further inquiries, appropriate remuneration should be $4.20 for ready prepared scripts. This is the current fee operating along with the essential pharmacy allowance and the isolated pharmacy allowance. Honourable members may have read media reports today that the Government had offered the equivalent of $4.55 per script during the inquiry process. That is in fact true. After discussions with Pharmacy WA, the Government made yet another concession in the interests of providing a reasonable climate for any PBRT inquiry. This $16.7m which is coming principally from the restructuring money provided in the Government's earlier package was unfortunately rejected. It was rejected both as a sign of goodwill and as an attempt to resolve the issues, just as the same `chemikaze' leadership rejected the $60m package and the other concessions that the Government has put forward over time. The response of this leadership was to up the ante from $4.55 per script operating pre-1 November to $5.05 per script. In 1990-91, that would cost $125m over and above the Government's $60m package as well as $128m extra from the consumer by the lifting of price controls, which those opposite would do. Quite frankly, all the way through this issue we have tried to negotiate with the leadership every step of the way but for every step that the Government has taken forward the hardliners in the leadership have taken at least one step back.

After yesterday's events in particular any reasonable person would have to ask the question: Does the leadership of pharmacy want the matter resolved or do some among the leadership want to create simply a lot of political heat? It is clear that some reasonable and moderate leaders really want to resolve the issues. It is also clear that a few others certainly do not. After blowing that $16.7m worth of reason, goodwill and sympathy yesterday, will they go to their members over the next couple of days and ask for more money from them for more advertisements and more action? On the one hand they try to convince people that they are serious about their remuneration and about the PBRT while, on the other hand, they knock back a $60m package. These are the sorts of questions that the membership of pharmacy in Australia today has to ask its leaders after its `chemikaze' leadership knocked back $16m yesterday.

I assure the House that the Government will continue to seek out reasonable pharmacy leaders and that it will continue to stick to the proper and due processes of the Tribunal and the law. When it is all boiled down what is at stake is the issue of responsible government and the protection of Australians through the pharmaceutical benefits scheme.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS POLICY: NEW SOUTH WALES

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the New South Wales Government's proposed amendments to that State's industrial relations legislation? What information can the Minister provide about the implications of this legislation for national wages policy and labour market reform?
—What does the Treasurer say?
—Order! The honourable member for Flinders will cease interjecting.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was that world famous land conveyancer again, was it?
—Order! The Minister might answer the question.

—There is legislation before the New South Wales Parliament, introduced by the New South Wales Government, to provide for enterprise agreements where 65 per cent of employees agree. Those agreements can be outside the New South Wales Industrial Relations Commission and, effectively, outside the wages system. They do not require anybody else's endorsement and they override any award. There are fundamental problems with this type of enterprise approach. Firstly, the approach is out of step with the significant changes occurring in Australian industry through award restructuring. Secondly, it makes nationally consistent and accredited industry training virtually impossible because each firm will do its own thing. Thirdly, it limits mobility between jobs-opportunities for employees to move though their industry-because people will be tied to a particular organisation. Fourthly, it is based on confrontation-individuals being set against the individual employer, working out their own deal, and those with muscle being able to exploit their position to the detriment of the rest of the work force and the wage system generally. Finally, as I have said on a previous occasion, this kind of proposal is a recipe for a wages explosion. Those opposite can cry and carry on about this, but industry recognises it.
—Oh, here we go!
—Order! The honourable member for Adelaide will cease interjecting.
—Industry organisations understand that. They know full well that if employees in one enterprise--
—Oh, come on. This is--
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Adelaide.

—If they get a large wage increase inevitably that will be followed in other enterprises-only in those cases where there is muscle. In New South Wales they have this wonderful arrangement where it will be secret; no-one will know about it. Only the people working in the enterprise and a particular employer will know about it. By this marvellous mechanism the New South Wales Government somehow thinks that it will prevent a flow-on to the rest of the work force and to the rest of the economy. Industry and everybody else who is concerned with a responsible wages policy know that that is a nonsense. Effectively what it does is fragment and destabilise the wage system and industrial relations generally. That is why we saw reports in the weekend press that the Australian Chamber of Manufactures in New South Wales, the New South Wales Employers Federation and the Metal Trades Industry Association in New South Wales all told the New South Wales Government that they do not want the legislation. We can add to that the numbers in the New South Wales Parliament and the New South Wales upper House because similarly they see the legislation, as do some Independents, as a pig in a poke proposal.

ANSWER.PARA: Under the New South Wales proposition and the industrial relations policy of those who sit opposite, there would be two wage systems: one operating within the Industrial Relations Commission under the national economic management policy; the other being a private operation with people doing their own thing. That can lead to only one result-a wage break-out, rampant inflation, an explosion in unemployment and, as I have said over and over again-we will keep saying it-a return to the old high unemployment days of the previous Fraser Government. The Opposition's industrial relations policy is virtually the same policy that the Fraser Government enacted and operated.
One honourable member opposite has a responsible approach to industrial relations, sees a role for consultation and recognises the dangers of confrontation in the policy espoused by the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —He won't last.
—Order! The honourable member for Canning!

—I refer to the honourable member for Goldstein. We have all seen what the New Right has done to the honourable member for Goldstein. There is one shining light over there who has had the courage, the balance and the wisdom to recognise that industrial relations is not about confrontation; it is about consistency and national economic management. He has put that forward and he is paying the price for it. It is the Copemans, the Kemps, the Costellos and the McLachlans-the New Right-that have put an end to the honourable member for Goldstein.

ANSWER.PARA: I conclude by saying that the question raised by the honourable member for Hunter has major import for the State of New South Wales. We will continue to have an industrial relations policy that takes account of national economic management, that will continue to be an essential part of economic management and, as the Treasurer has said, if you cannot run wages policy, Andrew, you cannot run the economy.

That is the assessment of the employers in New South Wales, but it is their assessment of the Opposition. What did the Opposition's shadow Minister for industrial relations say in a speech earlier this month? He said:
Our approach is for higher real wages based on higher productivity.
It is not surprising that the changes we will be pursuing next year are very close in shape to those John Fahey has outlined for New South Wales.
There we have it. The employers have analysed the Opposition's proposal in regard to wages--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, on a point of order: I would like to try again on standing order 145. The Prime Minister was asked, `What consideration will the Government be giving to Mr Ferris's recommendations?'. Of what relevance is this?
—Order! The Prime Minister was asked a question about the report that was tabled yesterday and the effect interest rates will have on exports. The Prime Minister is in order.

—As usual, the Opposition is never prepared to quote in full. The latter part of the question went to interest rates,. and I am pointing out what the Opposition probably does not know, that what happens to interest rates will be determined by what happens to fiscal and wages policy. I am determining, out of the mouth of the Opposition's own industrial relations shadow Minister, that there will be a wages explosion. He has said that what the Opposition is proposing is exactly the same as in New South Wales, and the employers of New South Wales have said there will be a wages explosion. So how, as a matter of logic, are we going to have anything other than higher interest rates under the policy of the Opposition when it has a looser fiscal policy and a wages explosion?

ANSWER.PARA: As a matter of logic, two things then follow: we will have higher interest rates and massive unemployment. That is the logic and the inevitability of what the Opposition is saying. So the Opposition should not get up in Question Time and talk about lower interest rates under the Opposition's policy. As I and the Treasurer have said, the inevitable position under the Opposition is higher interest rates, and in fact, under the fairly remorseless analysis to which the Opposition is now being exposed, it is gradually admitting it. The Leader of the Opposition, admittedly from a less than profound economic base of knowledge, was forced to say that for three years he could not guarantee a lowering of interest rates. That is what he said; it is on the record.

In regard to Mr Ferris's report, I simply make the point that, if one examines what has been happening in the economy, the structure is being put in place for an increase in exports in a range of areas, not only in our traditional areas of primary and mineral products but also in the areas of manufactured goods. We have created the conditions of a much more competitive economy, one in which there has been a much flatter movement in wages than at any other period in our history, and a tighter fiscal environment, out of which we now have investment as a higher proportion of gross domestic product than at any other time in our history. Investment is at its highest level ever at 13.5 per cent.

That investment, which in many respects has been reflected in our imports, is creating in this country a much more competitive situation. I ask the Leader of the Opposition and those opposite: Do they attack Access Economics? That is relevant to what Mr Ferris has said. Does the Opposition say that Access Economics is an unreliable organisation? If it does, it shoots its own Economic Action Plan right down. So, in regard to the issues that Mr Ferris talks about, as a result of the decisions that have already been taken by this Government the moves are in place, the projects are under way and the investment is in place to produce a significant increase in the level of exports generally and manufactured exports in particular.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Community Services and Health. The Treasurer has already alluded to the article on page one of the Sydney Morning Herald which is headed `Coalition plans Medicare shake-up'. Can the Minister advise the House whether the Government intends to maintain its current system of funding the additional cost of Medicare by payment according to means through a levy on taxable income?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are all aware that the coalition health policy has been dribbling out over the last year. In the Sydney Morning Herald this morning we got a particularly big dribble. I could almost call it a spit but I use that term metaphorically in view of the events of last week. From that particularly big dribble this morning it is clear that the coalition will try to force millions of Australians into expensive flat rate private insurance. The Government has no intention of changing the way the additional cost of Medicare is funded through a levy on taxable income. We believe that the Medicare levy arrangements ensure that payment is from each according to his or her ability to pay, providing health cover for all according to their need. As we recognise and as most economists have pointed out, this involves a redistribution from the richer sections of the population to the less well off and also from the healthy to the sick. We believe that that is the fairest system of all and one which Australians overwhelmingly support.

ANSWER.PARA: The Sydney Morning Herald suggests that the Opposition agenda is to destroy that system and introduce regressive arrangements which will favour the better off and hurt middle and low income earners. It is very much a re-run of 1976. We do not have to make guesses; we do not have to make comments. In structure it is very much what Fraser provided in his first scheme in 1976. Do honourable members remember when in 1975 he promised, `We will maintain Medibank'? Then as soon as he got into power he introduced a system, like that which is now proposed, whereby those who did not take out private health insurance were forced to pay a higher levy-in those days, a levy of 2.5 per cent. That was the penalty rate. We are being offered exactly the same and we are being offered it under the same sleazy pretence that Medicare will be preserved. We have it on record. When the honourable member for Tangney was talking to a group of vested interests in the health field, he was asked why would he retain the name `Medicare'. He said:
The political strategy is to recognise regrettably that the constituents whom we have to win are wider than this room and Medicare does have substantial support.

That is exactly what Fraser did in 1975. Some of the better off may find flat rate insurance a cheaper option than the current arrangements but it would be at the expense of low income earners, who would pay more, through an increased levy, to make up for that shortfall. It would destroy the stability, the security and the simplicity of Medicare and replace it with a costly and confusing mess. We know it would be a mess because it is exactly the same as the scheme that Fraser introduced in 1976, and he had to introduce four more after that to try to clear up the mess. Those opposite introduced a health scheme every other year and still they could not get it right.

All this is being introduced to solve a problem which does not exist. The honourable member for Tangney lives by platitudes and, in the end, he will die by platitudes. He says that the Opposition's aim is to resolve the imbalance between public and private sectors which has supposedly occurred under Medicare. More people than ever before are being treated in our public hospital system and more people than ever before are being treated in our private hospital system. Indeed, in the last year, of all the people treated in the hospital system, a bigger proportion were treated in the private hospital sector than ever before. The Opposition is therefore threatening to destroy Medicare to fix up an imbalance which has not occurred. The probable result of this is that some of the rich will pay less and the poor will certainly pay more. Is that not a familiar theme in this Opposition? It is another example of what we could call the capital gains syndrome-helping its rich mates at the expense of the poor and less well off. It is now proposing to do exactly the same in the health field.

Under the Opposition's plan there will be a redistribution in favour of the better off in the community. We recognise that we have done it the other way-we have taken money from the better off and given it to the poor under the Medicare scheme. We do not apologise for that. Those opposite are planning to reverse that. Finally, I remind the Opposition of just one thing-and this is very important to the Australian population whenever we have that election-and that is that by the time of the next election Medicare will have lasted a longer period than the five health schemes under Fraser.

—Is the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy aware of the comments of departing United States agriculture attache, Mr Jim Parker, that Australia's agricultural policies are trade distorting and that the United States `will bring them up in the GATT'? Can the Minister advise the House of the truth or otherwise of this allegation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Bendigo shows a lot more interest in rural trade policy than does the Opposition in this place. I think that at present he is 8 : 2 over the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. I have seen the comment. It appeared in last week's Australian Rural Times. There is a bit of ambivalence about the United States position. The Administration really has come out with a very gutsy position on agriculture and trade policy, and we have to compare that with what happens in Congress. For some time Mr Parker has been seeking to divert Australian attention away from United States trade and agricultural policies. That is okay; that is his job. But it is also relevant to the credibility of his comments. We need refer only to works by the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development and the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) to find out the truth with respect to various levels of protection for agricultural industries.

ANSWER.PARA: It is true that some assistance is provided to Australian agriculture. The Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) estimates that the average effective rate was about 9 per cent in 1987-88. Dairy price support accounts for about half of this assistance. That is mainly State based. The other support is through tariffs on sugar, wine, citrus, vegetables and tobacco and measures such as research and adjustment assistance. The National Farmers Federation conveniently ignores this assistance when it calls for the abolition of all protection in five years, but removing agricultural protection is very much the name of the game.

I have already said that Clayton Yeutter, Secretary of Agriculture, has put on the table a very gutsy statement. This country and this House owe a great debt to the Minister for Trade Negotiations for the negotiating position he recently achieved with the Cairns Group at Chiang Mai. It is very much the main game. Once we get some GATT rules-that is our priority-we will meet them. We are sure that meeting those rules, whatever they are, will require minimal adjustment to our policies. Like everything else on micro-economic reform, this is in stark contrast to the previous Government. After the last GATT round Doug Anthony actually bragged that the Government had avoided reducing any of Australia's manufacturing industry protection. That is the measure of the Opposition's failure for Australian agriculture.

I did not mind United States scrutiny of our policies, but they need to be looked at a little more closely than Mr Parker has looked at them. There is a distinction between pooling and dual pricing, and a distinction between Commonwealth and State arrangements. Some 40 per cent of that 9 per cent estimate by the IAC actually comes from the States. Of the 10 Commonwealth statutory marketing authorities only two-the Australian Dried Fruits Corporation and the Australian Dairy Corporation-hold domestic prices above export prices. We recognise that this is assistance. The IAC values this assistance at $17m and $190m to those two industries, but only two authorities, the Dried Fruits Corporation and the Australian Wheat Board, operate pooling arrangements. But pooling is not assistance; it is not a trade distorting subsidy and that is what the GATT round is all about. In relation to wheat, we now have domestic market deregulation and, like the Australian Wool Corporation, the Australian Wheat Board takes world prices. That is why I am absolutely confident that pooling would survive GATT scrutiny. No GATT rule says that the price of every commodity on world markets should be exactly the same, particularly when one is not selling an identical product. Australian standard white wheat is not hard red western wheat from the United States of America, for example. There is simply no comparsion with the massive assistance that the USA provides its farmers-assistance which goes well beyond the controversial export enhancement program.

I would like to conclude on this note-and the honourable member for Fraser will be particularly interested in this topic: I recently chaired the Food and Agriculture Organisation conference for a week in Rome. The Director-General pointed out that $290,000m is now spent on agricultural subsidisation and protection in the world. This is to be compared with the $42,000m that is spent on aid from the developed to the developing countries. Even that $42,000m has to be contrasted with the reverse aid flow, which now pours in from the poorer countries with these massive international debts, that is now at a level of about $43,000m. That is the nature of the problem with which we are dealing and words by Mr Parker to try to distract our attention from the main game are rather ridiculous.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the Hawke-Keating Government to bring about a sustainable reduction in interest rates.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hewson Dr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Every Australian is now acutely aware of the existence of record levels of home loan and business interest rates that have occurred for the second time in seven years under the Hawke-Keating Government. Interest rates are a very good barometer of the extent of the economic mismanagement of this Government. In moving this matter of public importance and recognising the Government's passion for living in the past and looking back over the past, I thought it important to place on the record an assessment of this Government's performance in terms of interest rates. For over seven years the Government has found it impossible to achieve a sustainable reduction in interest rates. Every time that it has tried to lower interest rates, the attempt has blown up in its face. Any reductions have been short-lived and have soon proved to be unsustainable. The one clear message that sticks out of the mess of the past seven years is that the Hawke-Keating Government has never had the policies to lower interest rates, principally because it has never had policies to lower inflation.

SPEECH.PARA: On two occasions-first in late 1984 and again from early 1987 to early 1988-the Government sought to lower interest rates artificially, but in both cases it was very soon swamped by economic reality. In 1984 the reality was the collapse of our exchange rate in a series of crises during the period 1985 to 1986, which saw interest rates double. In 1987-88 the reality was our balance of payments and our debt problems. We know that interest rates are now at record levels of 17 to 18 per cent for home buyers and 21 to 25 per cent for business. We continue with the risk that there could be another Australian dollar crisis down the track.

To be fair to the Government, we should go back and see whether it has misled us on this matter. The fact is that in 1983 the Government made it quite clear that it did not have an anti-inflation strategy. The best example of that was the interview that the then shadow Treasurer and now Treasurer (Mr Keating) had with John Laws on a Sydney radio program when he said:

So, fighting inflation first is frankly a failure and we've gotta ditch it and we've gotta go for growth with a positive incomes policy and all I can say is that, if we are elected to office, we'll do our best to make it work. I'm not sure we can make it work, but we're going to give it a good shot.

What we have seen in seven years of that good shot is unmitigated disaster from the point of view of people who are struggling to buy their homes, or those who are trying to run businesses in this country. There is no doubt that the Government went for growth in a big way in 1983-84. It was elected basically on the promise of stimulating fiscal policy, running an accommodating easy monetary policy, because it had this thing called the accord which would take care of inflation. It did not have to worry about inflation, because the accord would do the job.

Honourable members might remember the Government's 1983 package, which was in sharp contrast to our package comprising 80 pages-the Government's package covered only one page and about $2.7 billion worth of initiatives, all of which were unfunded. The Government has stayed with that principle of unfunded tax relief and other changes to the Budget ever since. What happened was that by late 1984 the Treasurer was becoming very anxious that interest rates were not coming down, so he leant on the Reserve Bank of Australia on that classic occasion-the Bank Holiday massacre of August 1984-and he forced the pace on interest rates. Financial market reality struck him right between the eyes in early 1985 and again in 1986 in the form of three separate major exchange rate crises which saw our exchange rate fall by almost 40 per cent on a trade weighted basis.

In response, the Treasurer then tried to tighten fiscal policy, but he did not do enough. Despite warnings from his Department and other official advisers in early 1987 that are now on the record, he went ahead and forced the pace on interest rates for the second time. He eased interest rates and monetary policy in the lead-up to the July 1987 election. He then again eased it in late 1987 and early 1988 in the lead-up to the New South Wales election. What has happened? Economic reality has again struck home. We have had 20 months of his reversing that easing of policy.

It is important to note that the Reserve Bank now identifies 1987 as being the genesis of our current problems. It used the words `genesis of our current problem' in relation to what occurred in early 1987. In the past few days in a very good article, a couple of Reserve Bank economists have suggested that the current wage pressures and the wage explosion pressures operated under this Government and its accord could have been avoided if the pace of monetary policy easing had not been forced in early 1987. As a result, interest rates are at record levels and, in the current circumstances, financial markets are now decidedly nervous about where they are going and what the Government will do. In that regard, I will read from yesterday's Chanticleer column, which I think was very revealing in relation to the current situation. It states:

The international traders with `hot money' sitting in Australia because it is the higher yielding currency can play Bob Hawke and Paul Keating for a break. They know there are probably two options left for Hawke's re-election-another wage-tax trade-off first thing in 1990; when that doesn't settle the markets, the only thing left is debauching the currency. Any attempt to engineer a drop in rates would result in no more than a blip, and possibly a devastating run on the currency which would lead in turn to even higher interest rates later as inflation leapt out of control.

The Australian Financial Review yesterday suggested a rerun of the history of 1985-86 in current circumstances where, if the Government tries to start to lower interest rates artificially without adjusting other policies, they will again be blown out of the water by a financial market which will substantially lose confidence in the Government's management and money will flood from this country.

In recent days the Treasurer and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) have tried to distract attention from this economic reality with the things that they have said about their wages policy, the way the accord is supposed to be working, and so on. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The modernisation of Australia's extradition laws has been an integral part of this Government's strategy in the war against crime. It is no secret that crime is increasingly taking on an international perspective. There is no starker example of the international dimensions of crime than the drug trade. Not only is there an importation of illicit drugs but also there is the associated exportation of money from Australia to pay for this filthy merchandise. Often legitimate international business channels are used to make just such payments. This Government has taken significant initiatives to combat crime within Australia. The Proceeds of Crime Act 1987 provides for a comprehensive regime of freezing and confiscation designed to attack the very motive for crime-profit. The Cash Transaction Reports Act 1988 establishes regimes for the reporting of significant cash transactions, for the reporting of suspect transactions and for the verification of identity of persons opening accounts. These measures will greatly assist law enforcement by producing criminal intelligence and creating a money trail for large amounts of cash.

Having established these measures domestically, the next step is to reach agreement with other nations that will facilitate international cooperation in the fight against crime. The Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act 1987 provides just such a mechanism. Where Australia has a mutual assistance relationship with a foreign nation many of these domestic remedies may be available to that other nation. Similarly, domestic remedies regarding the freezing and confiscation of assets in that country may be able to be used by Australian law enforcement agencies. This Government has actively pursued the negotiation of mutual assistance treaties with other nations and to date has concluded nine treaties, with 15 in various stages of negotiations.

Complementary to these measures is the modernisation of Australia's extradition relationships. The Government formed a task force to negotiate modern bilateral extradition treaties or extradition arrangements. So far treaties or arrangements have been negotiated with 25 countries, with 14 in various stages of negotiations. In 1988 the Parliament passed a modern Extradition Act. In light of the experience with the Act over the past 12 months or so, a need for some technical finetuning of the legislation has become apparent. The Bill before the House contains those technical amendments.

I propose to deal only briefly with the more significant of these amendments. As section 11 of the Act now stands, it is not possible to list in regulations all countries to which Australia can extradite for crimes created pursuant to multilateral treaties such as the hijacking convention and the convention for the protection of internationally protected persons. It is clearly desirable that all Australians be able to ascertain easily the crimes for which extradition can be considered and all the countries to which Australia can extradite for those crimes. The amendments to section 11 are designed to enable the regulations to comprehensively list the countries to which persons may be extradited for multilateral offences. Other amendments streamline Australia's extradition relationship with New Zealand where a person consents to being surrendered to New Zealand. Finally, a new provision is inserted into the Extradition Act 1988 which will give police power to arrest, without warrant, a person who is about to abscond. A detailed explanation of all the amendments is set out in the explanatory memorandum. The amendments included in the Bill will involve no additional expenditure. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill, and commend the Bill to the House.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mrs Kelly, for Mr Willis, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly The Hon R.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mrs KELLY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

A central plank in the Government's micro-economic reform agenda for restructuring the public sector is that government business enterprises (GBEs) should be as efficient as possible and responsive to consumers' needs. The GBEs within the transport and communications portfolio, in addition to producing final goods and services for consumers, also produce intermediate inputs for the rest of the economy, with a resulting impact on Australia's overall cost structures and the ability of Australian businesses to compete internationally.

The Government sees the commercialisation of GBEs as a necessary and fundamental pre-condition to improvements in efficiency. GBEs such as the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) and the Federal Airports Corporation are therefore being placed on a more commercial footing, bringing them more into line with the disciplines traditionally associated with private sector enterprises.

This Bill, together with the Federal Airports Corporation Amendment Bill 1989, represents the legislative changes necessary to finalise the Government's reform of its aviation industry enterprises. The reform package accords broadly with reform packages for other enterprises in the transport and communications portfolio which were announced in the ministerial statement of 25 May 1988, entitled `Reshaping the Transport and Communications Government Business Enterprises'.

However, as a relatively recent piece of legislation, the Civil Aviation Act 1988 already incorporates a number of measures which accord closely with changes made to other public authorities through the GBE reform process. For example, the Act establishes corporate planning and financial targets as the basis for Government oversight of the CAA. To some extent, therefore, the Bill represents finetuning of the existing strategic controls over the Authority to bring them more closely into line with other reform packages agreed by the Government. It also removes a range of detailed controls which the Government still exercises over the activities of the Authority.

In addition to presenting the package of reforms for the CAA, the Bill also includes provisions relating to the carriage of dangerous goods, review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal of decisions by the Authority to suspend a licence or certificate on safety grounds pending investigation, clarification of the provisions relating to statutory liens on aircraft and protection from state laws where the CAA performs a function directly related to the regulation of air safety. The Bill also implements two amendments arising from recommendations of the first report of the Air Safety Regulation Review Task Force.

I now turn to specific provisions contained in the Bill. A key element in establishing an environment within the CAA which will encourage greater responsiveness and efficiency is the proposal to remove Public Service Act coverage of its employees, thereby making the CAA Board the direct employer and allowing a more flexible and business-like approach to the management of the Authority. Transitional arrangements contained in the Bill provide that existing staff will continue to be employed, initially, on the same terms and conditions. Mobility provisions of the Public Service Act will continue to apply.

Another major change provided for in the Bill is the scrutiny of proposed statutory charges levied by the CAA under the Act by the Prices Surveillance Authority (PSA). The Government believes that there is a need for visible checks and balances to be put in place to ensure that there is no perceived misuse of the CAA's monopoly position. The Minister will retain the formal power to disallow charges and be given the power to set replacement charges. The provisions are intended to enhance the effectiveness of the Minister's present power to approve or disapprove charges, by providing the Minister with the opportunity to consider any report of the PSA before making his or her decision and by enabling the Minister to set charges to replace those which are unacceptable.

In line with the philosophy of moving from oversight of day-to-day operations to an emphasis on results and board accountability, the Bill removes a range of day-to-day controls exercised by Government, including controls over the terms and conditions of individual borrowings, the approval of individual contracts, the purchase of shares and the establishment of subsidiaries and partnerships. These are now appropriately the responsibility of the board.

Other provisions in the Bill relating to appointment and dismissal of board members, conduct of board meetings and the appointment and powers of the Chief Executive Officer reflect more clearly the respective roles of the Minister and the board and clarify issues of administration of the Authority. Although the CAA currently pays a range of Commonwealth and State taxes and duties, it is exempt from payment of Commonwealth income tax. This Bill removes that exemption and provides for the CAA to be fully subject to Commonwealth income tax with effect from 1 July 1991.

As I indicated earlier, other provisions in the Bill, unrelated to the reform measures outlined above, include measures to implement, as far as practicable, the recommendations of the Air Safety Regulations Review Task Force's first report that the cost to industry of proposed standards of aviation safety should be taken into account by the Authority, and that significant offences in the regulations relating to crucial areas of air safety should be included in the Act.

The Bill also strengthens the role of the Authority in specifying conditions for the carriage or consignment of dangerous goods and provides for the establishment of dangerous goods training programs for air operators and freight forwarders. The Act currently requires the Authority to grant individual permissions to carry or consign dangerous goods and to specify conditions in respect of each such permission. The section does not enable the Authority to grant general permissions. The amendments will empower the Authority to grant general permissions, in addition to the specific permissions currently provided for. Such permissions would be specified in civil aviation orders or the civil aviation regulations and would be subject to such conditions as the Authority specifies in the orders or regulations, as the case may be, in relation to the particular permission. In order to ensure the effective screening of dangerous goods the Act will be amended to provide that an air operator must not carry air cargo and a freight forwarder must not accept any air cargo unless it is accompanied by a declaration of the contents of the cargo.

Provisions in the Act relating to statutory liens on aircraft have been amended to rectify a deficiency in the definition of that term, and to extend the existing protection offered to the Authority and its officers to cover actions brought for recompense of economic loss suffered as a result of seizure of aircraft under the statutory liens provisions. The Act already provides that, when an aircraft has been seized under a statutory lien, then neither the Authority nor its officers may be sued for loss of, or damage to, the aircraft.

The Bill also provides that a State law will not apply to the Authority or its property where it is necessary for the Authority to perform functions directly related to the purpose of regulating air safety. The particular functions are the provision of air route and airway facilities, air traffic control and flight services on aerodromes, rescue and firefighting services and search and rescue services. It is intended that this particular provision will only be used where the matter is essential to the performance of the Authority and negotiations with a State or local government authority have been unable to result in resolutions.

Under regulation 268 of the Civil Aviation Regulations the Authority may suspend a licence or certificate if the Authority thinks there are facts or circumstances which would justify a suspension or cancellation on one of the grounds specified in regulation 269. Among the grounds specified in regulation 269 is the fact that the holder of the licence or certificate has failed in his or her duty with respect to any matter affecting the safe operation of an aircraft or that he or she has contravened a direction or instruction with respect to a matter affecting the safe navigation and operation of an aircraft.

A suspension under regulation 268 ceases no later than 28 days after the suspension takes effect. The purpose of such a suspension is to allow the Authority to carry out an investigation of the matter. Unfortunately what has been occurring is that a person who has received a notice of suspension under regulation 268 has immediately sought, and invariably obtained, a stay under section 41 of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act. This has defeated the objective of regulation 268 because the Authority has not been able to carry out its investigation and because the AAT in determining the stay is not restricted to considering the safety issues but may grant a stay if it considers it desirable to do so after taking into account the interests of the applicant. In some instances a decision made on safety grounds has been overturned by the AAT on economic or hardship grounds. Accordingly the Act will be amended to provide that, where the Authority has suspended a licence or certificate under regulation 268 on the safety grounds specified in regulation 269 (1) (c) or (e), then that decision will not be reviewable under the AAT Act.
On the recommendation of the Attorney-General's Department, the Bill amends existing pecuniary penalty provisions to bring the Act into line with recent amendments to the Crimes Act 1914.

The Bill has no immediate financial implications for the Commonwealth, although, over time, the reforms of the Civil Aviation Authority included in the Bill are expected to enhance the efficiency of the Authority and improve its returns to the Commonwealth. The imposition of income tax on the Authority for 1991-92 and subsequent financial years is expected to result in increased revenue to the Commonwealth. The amounts cannot be accurately quantified at this time, as they depend on a number of factors including the profitability of the Authority, the extent of tax deductions obtained and the prevailing tax rates. I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.

DEBATE.TITLE: OCCUPATIONAL SUPERANNUATION (REASONABLE BENEFIT LIMITS) AMENDMENT BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Peter Morris, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PETER MORRIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of the Occupational Superannuation (Reasonable Benefit Limits) Amendment Bill is to amend the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act 1987 and the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 to implement changes to the reasonable benefit limits and related taxation measures which the Treasurer (Mr Keating) announced in his 1988 May economic statement and his Budget Speech of 15 August 1989.

These changes are an important part of the Government's retirement incomes policy. A basic objective of that policy is to increase significantly the role occupational superannuation plays in Australia's retirement income arrangements. For superannuation to play this role, it must be economically sustainable, attractive as a savings vehicle, and equitable.

The changes to the taxation treatment of superannuation enacted in June this year put superannuation on an economically sustainable basis for the long term while retaining the concessional taxation treatment of superannuation and like benefits. The changes to the reasonable benefit arrangements proposed by this Bill bring more equity into these arrangements.

The most important effect of this Bill will be the establishment, from 1 July 1990, of the reasonable benefit limit as the maximum amount of benefits a person is permitted to receive on a concessionally taxed basis. Previously, it was the maximum that could be paid out of a superannuation fund. With the very limited exemptions I shall mention shortly, the reasonable benefit limit will apply to all concessionally taxed benefits regardless of whether those benefits are provided by public or private sector sources, whether they are provided by superannuation funds, rollover funds or employers, and whether they are funded or unfunded. This important initiative redresses the long standing inequity of private sector superannuation benefits being subject to limits while public sector benefits were exempt. It also closes the loophole in the previous arrangements whereby those in private sector funds who have the ability to so arrange their affairs could receive concessionally taxed benefits in excess of the limits by rolling over before age 65 or taking additional benefits as `golden handshakes'.

The Government has announced transitional arrangements for the application of the limits to roll-over benefits, but a number of representations have been received that those arrangements did not go far enough. The Government is currently examining whether those arrangements can be extended to alleviate any unreasonable difficulties caused by the new arrangements. The only concessionally taxed benefits which will not be subject to the limits will be bona fide redundancy, genuine invalidity and approved early retirement scheme benefits within the income tax laws.

The Bill also proposes that the method for determining the limits be set by the government of the day. This initiative was foreshadowed by the then Minister Assisting the Treasurer, the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories (Mr Holding), in his second reading speech introducing the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1987. The limits and the method for determining whether a benefit is within or in excess of the limits will be prescribed in the Occupational Superannuation Standards Regulations. The regulations prescribing the limits will be made once the Bill is enacted. They will give effect to the announcements made by the Government in the May 1988 economic statement and in the Budget on 15 August 1989 on the methods of calculating and administering the limits.

Mr Deputy Speaker, before going over the the main provisions of the Bill, I would like to mention the main features of those announcements. They represent substantial improvements for those prepared to save for their retirement. First, most members of superannuation funds will be able to save on a concessionally taxed basis enough to provide a CPI indexed life pension or annuity of up to 75 per cent of a person's highest average salary over any three previous consecutive years. A lower percentage will apply to higher income earners. The limit will be high enough to allow the pension or annuity to revert to a surviving spouse at up to 85 per cent of the amount of the primary pension and be payable for 10 years even if both beneficiaries die beforehand. The lump sum equivalent of these benefits is up to 11.25 years salary. It represents an increase of up to approximately 15 per cent in the limits for those previously saving for pensions and up to 60 per cent for those previously saving for lump sums.

Second, a person will be eligible for benefits at this level if he or she takes at least half of his or her benefits as a pension or annuity which meets certain minimum standards. Where more than half of a person's benefits are taken as a lump sum, a lower limit applies, of up to seven times highest average salary. These arrangements reflect the Government's view that pensions and annuities are the preferred form of benefits, while not denying a person the choice to take his or her benefits as lump sums. Third, highest average salary will be indexed where a person takes all of his or her benefits, excluding undeducted contributions, as a pension or annuity which meets minimum standards or preserves all of those benefits to age 65.

The final feature of the Government's announcements I would like to mention is that the new measures are designed to encourage longer participation in the work force and the retention of benefits to retirement. This has been achieved by removing the penalty in the previous arrangements whereby a person's reasonable benefit limit, and his or her entitlement to concessionally taxed benefits, fell if work commitments were wound down prior to reaching full retirement. Under the new arrangements, highest average salary will be indexed after age 55 when a person works a minimum amount after that age.

I now turn to the arrangements proposed in the Bill for the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner to administer the limits set by the Government. Providers of concessionally taxed benefits, namely, superannuation funds, approved deposit funds, employers, life insurance companies and registered organisations such as friendly societies will be required to advise the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner of prescribed details of benefits provided to individuals. Upon receipt of this information, the Commissioner will be required to determine the amount of the benefit paid to the person that is within the reasonable benefit limits and the amount of the benefit, if any, that is in excess of the limits prescribed under the regulations. The Commissioner will be required to advise the recipient of the benefit of his determination and of the basis of that determination.

The Bill provides that amounts up to the reasonable benefit limits are to be taxed concessionally and amounts in excess of the limits are required to be paid as a lump sum, to be included in assessable income and taxed at marginal rates. Taxation of the excess amount at marginal rates together with a tax on the contributions to the fund, is intended to recoup the tax relief gained during accrual of the excess amount in a concessionally taxed environment. This measure will discourage deliberate overfunding and payment of excess benefits because the excess benefit received after tax will generally not exceed that from a non-concessional savings vehicle. This will allow the Government to remove the direct restrictions on the provision of excess benefits by superannuation funds when the relevant regulations are made. These restrictions have been the subject of complaint by the industry for a long time. It will also ensure that no-one can receive an amount of concessionally taxed benefits in excess of his or her entitlements as prescribed by the limits. This is an important initiative to ensure the superannuation tax arrangements are equitable in the long term.

Providers of superannuation benefits will not be required to advise the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner of any part of the superannuation benefit which consists of undeducted contributions or concessional components, that is, bona fide redundancy, genuine invalidity or approved early retirement scheme payments; nor will providers of superannuation benefits generally be required to advise the Commissioner where they pay a death benefit to a dependant of a member of the fund. These components will not generally be counted towards the reasonable benefit limits.

To assist the Commissioner to administer the limits effectively, the Bill proposes that, where a person is paid a benefit subject to the reasonable benefit limits, that person be permitted to provide his or her tax file number to the provider of the benefit for forwarding to the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner. The Commissioner requires the person's tax file number so that he can be certain that his determination of whether a benefit is within the person's reasonable benefit limit is correct, after taking into account benefits received in the past or from different sources. Where the person does not provide his or her tax file number, the Commissioner will not be obliged to make a determination.

Provision of a tax file number by a person to the provider of the benefit will be on the same basis as tax file numbers are to be provided to financial institutions. There will be no compulsion to provide a tax file number but, where it is not provided, the provider of the benefit will be required to deduct tax from the benefit at the top marginal rate. Moreover, where the Commissioner does not make a determination because the tax file number is not supplied, the Bill provides that eligible termination payments, other than concessional components of those payments and undeducted contributions, are to be taxed at marginal rates.

The Bill requires that the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner comply with the guidelines for the collection, storage and use of tax file numbers and the information privacy principles prescribed under the Privacy Act 1988. The Privacy Commissioner has been consulted on the proposals contained in the Bill on the collection, storage and use of tax file numbers by the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner for the purpose of administering the reasonable benefit limits. The Privacy Commissioner has advised that the administration of the reasonable benefit limits is clearly a tax related function and that, to ensure there are no mistakes of identification, it is administratively necessary for the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner to receive and hold tax file numbers.

The Bill proposes changes to the definition of a superannuation fund to enable payment of retirement benefits even where a person has not retired from full time or part time employment. This provision will enable people in part time employment to retain benefits in a superannuation fund until age 70 at the latest and persons in full time employment to do so while they are in employment but would enable the benefits to be paid at age 65 if the persons so desired. The Bill also proposes that a person be able to appeal decisions of the Commissioner on his or her reasonable benefit limit and whether a benefit received is within that limit. The person will be able to request the Commissioner to reconsider his decision within 21 days of receipt of the Commissioner's determination. Where the person is dissatisfied with the Commissioner's decision arising out of the reconsideration, he or she may appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal for a review of the Commissioner's decision.

Finally, the Bill includes other taxation measures associated with the implementation of the new reasonable benefit limits. Those measures will ensure there is no misuse of concessionally taxed superannuation funds and will prevent funds circumventing the proposed taxation arrangements for excessive benefits.
Financial Impact Statement

It is not possible to quantify the effect on revenue of the changes to the administration of the reasonable benefit limits and the other taxation measures as it will, to a large extent, depend on the options exercised by individuals. However, I would expect that the revenue impact of the reasonable benefit limits arrangements will be neutral in 1989-90 and in 1990-91. In the longer term savings could be expected in outlays on social welfare payments.
I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.
