PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Simmons, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Simmons The Hon D.W.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SIMMONS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence Science and Personnel)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill proposes a variety of amendments to Acts dealing with defence matters. The more important amendments: amend defence force retirement and death benefits legislation to increase the orphans' benefit from $702 to $5,000; remove restrictions on the Chief of the Defence Force's power to make single service command appointments and organisational arrangements; modify provisions relating to the enlistment of soldiers and sailors to enable the open ended enlistment scheme to operate more effectively; and amend Commonwealth Acts to replace references to the Joint Intelligence Organisation with references to the Defence Intelligence Organisation.

Other amendments: remove redundant provisions dealing with seniority; amend the Defence Force Discipline Act 1982 to replace obsolete references to the offence of rape with references to the current Australian Capital Territory provisions that have replaced that former offence; and amend the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act (No. 1) 1985 to remove an unnecessary provision dealing with allotments. I will now deal with the more important amendments. The other changes are explained in the explanatory memorandum.
Orphans' Benefits

The increases in the orphans' benefits proposed by the amendments in schedule 2 are those that I announced in my statement on 11 May 1989 in responding to the report on personnel wastage in the Australian Defence Force (ADF) by the Defence Subcommittee of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade-the Cross Committee. Honourable members may recall that I said then that the levels of orphans' benefits under the Defence Force retirement and death benefits (DFRDB) scheme and the Defence Forces retirement benefits (DFRB) scheme were considerably less than those under the Commonwealth superannuation schemes. The increase of some $4,300 for each orphan will correct the situation. The total benefits payable in respect of the orphans of a deceased member or pensioner will be capped at the maximum rate of pension that would have been payable to the member or pensioner. Some 131 orphans under the DFRDB scheme and 11 under the DFRB scheme will benefit immediately from the increases.
Command Power of the Chief of the Defence Force

Current command arrangements allow the Chief of the Defence Force to command all operations conducted by the Australian Defence Force. These arrangements have been put into place as a result of the ongoing process of refining the command of the Australian Defence Force. They are the result of implementing the recommendations of the study into ADF command arrangements conducted at the Chief of the Defence Force's direction by then Brigadier John Baker. The existing legislation obliges the Chief of the Defence Force to implement single service appointments and organisational arrangements through the service Chief of Staff. To provide the appropriate legal basis for the current arrangements, these restrictions upon the Chief of the Defence Force's command power need to be removed. The amendments make the necessary changes to the Defence Act and Naval Defence Act. The amendments in no way detract from the provision of command appointments and organisational arrangements under the Acts, as remaining provisions will contain adequate authority for these matters. There will therefore be no need to replace the provisions that have been omitted or repealed. The new command arrangements have been implemented with the support of the service Chiefs of Staff. While they no longer conduct operations, they continue to train and administer their respective arms of the Defence Force and provide advice as the professional heads of their respective service.
Open Ended Enlistment

In 1987 the Defence Act and Naval Defence Act were amended to allow service administrators to offer enlistment to retiring age as well as enlistment for a fixed period. A soldier or sailor enlisted until retiring age may claim his or her discharge on giving an appropriate period of notice, which in relation to members of the permanent forces is 12 months or such lesser period determined by a Chief of Staff. It was the intention of service administrators at that time to offer, initially, enlistment for a fixed period followed by the option of extension until retiring age. Service administrators now consider that it is more efficient to enlist a soldier or sailor initially until retiring age but require that a minimum period of service be required before a discharge may be claimed. The amendments proposed to the Defence Act and Naval Defence Act include a provision so that a soldier or sailor of the permanent forces who has enlisted until retiring age does not have a right to claim a discharge during the first six years of service, or such lesser period as a Chief of Staff determines. Historically, six years is the minimum initial period of service required to be served.

To enable effective implementation of the open ended enlistment scheme, the amendments proposed require that the approval of a Chief of Staff be required for any variation or withdrawal of a claim for discharge. This amendment is required to avoid manipulation of the procedure of claiming a discharge. Factors required to be taken into account by a Chief of Staff in determining a lesser period of service before which a discharge may be claimed and in considering approval of a variation or withdrawal of a claim for discharge are included in the proposed amendment. It will still be open to a soldier or sailor to request a discharge at any time.
Joint Intelligence Organisation

On 1 March 1989 the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) announced some changes to defence intelligence arrangements, and in particular the combining of the functions of the Joint Intelligence Organisation with those of the intelligence group in the Australian Defence Force headquarters. The Minister also announced that this restructured body will be known as the Defence Intelligence Organisation. The new name better reflects the body's central role in the preparation of defence intelligence assessments and the provision of operational intelligence for the Australian Defence Force. The amendments make consequential name changes to the various Commonwealth Acts containing references to the Joint Intelligence Organisation. These changes will enable the formal renaming of the body.
Financial Impact Statement
It is estimated that the increase in the orphans' benefits will cost approximately $584,000 a year. The other provisions of the Bill have no financial impact.
I commend the Bill to the House. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Staples, for Mr Dawkins, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALKER.NAME: Mr STAPLES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Housing and Aged Care)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Superannuation Bill 1989 introduces a package of reforms in superannuation for Commonwealth employees. It entails the most far-reaching reforms in 67 years. It will bring Commonwealth superannuation within the mainstream of Australian superannuation schemes. It will provide benefits that will be far more attractive to members at less cost to taxpayers. The new scheme will provide: The opportunity of membership to all employees; a choice of lump sum or pension benefits; flexible contribution rates for members; substantially improved resignation benefits; and significantly tightened invalidity provisions.

The new scheme will be the main superannuation scheme for Commonwealth employees. The scheme will cover all Commonwealth sector employees, except those of government business enterprises, and other Commonwealth agencies, that have separate superannuation schemes for their employees. Membership will be compulsory for all permanent employees, and optional for all other staff, subject only to a three-month qualifying period. Superannuation will in future be available to around 35,000 Commonwealth employees who are unable to join the current scheme. The form for the employer benefit in the current scheme is a non-commutable pension.

Consistent with the Government's policy that lump sums are a legitimate form of superannuation benefit, the new scheme will provide a choice of lump sum or pension benefits. The standard benefit on age retirement will be a lump sum. However, members will be able to convert 50 per cent or more of their retirement lump sum to an indexed pension, at very attractive rates. In effect, the new scheme provides a subsidy in order to encourage people to take a pension. This encouragement is in addition to the general tax incentives favouring pensions over lump sums. The scheme will give Commonwealth employees access to the lump sums available to private sector employees, and be consistent with the Government's retirement income policy.

These reforms are based firmly on the principle that Commonwealth employees should have the same superannuation options and be subject to the same regulations and restrictions as the rest of the work force. The new scheme will comply with the occupational superannuation standards, including the reasonable benefits limits. In the current scheme, the member contribution rate is a minimum of 5 per cent of salary at all times. In the new scheme, members will be able to contribute between 2 per cent and 10 per cent of salary. This will enable members to tailor their contributions to suit their changing financial circumstances throughout their life. Benefits will be linked to member contributions, and will include the 3 per cent productivity benefit. The maximum retirement benefit for members on average salaries of between $25,000 and $37,560 a year will be a lump sum of eight times average salary, or a fully indexed pension of 80 per cent of average salary. Members on higher salaries will have maximum benefits below eight times average salary in accordance with the reasonable benefit limits. Members on lower salaries will be able to receive a lump sum of up to $200,000. This may be converted to a fully indexed pension of up to $20,000 per year.

One of the most significant initiatives in the new scheme is a major improvement in resignation benefits. This will correct a major inequity. More than two-thirds of members of the existing scheme receive no employer benefits because they resign before retirement. On resignation, members of the new scheme will be entitled to a refund of their own contributions with interest. They will be able either to take this in cash on resignation or to leave it in the scheme until retirement. Members who resign will also receive their 3 per cent productivity benefit accumulated with interest when they ultimately retire from the work force. In addition, a member's entitlement to the remainder of the employer-funded benefit will start to phase in after one year's membership. After four years' membership, employees will be entitled to the full employer benefit at retirement. Thus, all members will receive a Commonwealth superannuation benefit on retirement, even if they had resigned from Commonwealth employment many years beforehand.

These significant improvements in superannuation benefits for Commonwealth employees will be funded primarily by tightening invalidity arrangements. While many of the persons receiving invalidity benefits in the current scheme are genuine invalids, there is evidence that invalidity retirement has been abused. A significant proportion of members have been retired on invalidity grounds by their employer against the advice of Commonwealth medical officers. Invalidity rates in the current scheme have been five to 10 times private sector rates. These invalidity rorts must stop. The current scheme provides a significant financial incentive towards invalidity retirement rather than early age retirement.

In the new scheme, invalidity benefits will be more closely aligned to age retirement benefits. The assumed retirement age for calculating invalidity benefits will be reduced from 65 to 60, better reflecting existing retirement patterns. Administration of invalidity retirement will be tightened. To receive an invalidity pension, a member will have to meet the definition of invalidity in the occupational superannuation standards. That is, a pension will be paid if the member is unlikely ever to work again in any occupation for which he or she is reasonable qualified by education, training or experience. Retraining potential will also be taken into account. The trustees of the scheme will have the final say on whether invalidity benefits are to be paid. These measures will eliminate the rorts, while still protecting genuine invalids.

Moreover, invalidity benefits will no longer be subject to a complex administrative process which involves determining whether the cause of invalidity is related to medical conditions existing at entry up to 20 years earlier. For those presently caught by this process, invalidity benefits will be improved, in some cases very substantially. For others, except for career employees, invalidity benefits will generally be less attractive than in the current Commonwealth superannuation schemes (CSS). In all cases, genuine invalids will be provided with an adequate pension having regard to their service to the Commonwealth.

Current employees will be able to benefit from these reforms. Contributors to the existing scheme, except employees of government business enterprises, and other agencies, that have their own superannuation scheme, will be given an option to transfer to the new scheme over the 12 months from 1 July 1990. Others, for example people on extended leave without pay or who have a deferred benefit, will have an option to transfer to the new scheme when they rejoin a relevant area of Commonwealth employment. There will be a major information campaign to ensure all members have access to adequate information to make an informed transfer decision. Transferring members will receive a credit in the new scheme based on the standard transfer value in the existing scheme of 3.5 times their accumulated basic contributions, plus their 3 per cent productivity benefit.

I will now discuss the financial aspects of the new scheme. The ending of invalidity rorts means that the improvements in the new scheme can be provided at no additional cost to taxpayers. The consulting actuaries, TPF and C and the Australian Government Actuary, have certified that, for existing employees, the cost of the new scheme will be virtually identical to the cost of the current CSS, in net present value terms, after allowance is made for tax and social security clawbacks.

The Government has decided that the 3 per cent productivity benefit will be funded from 1 July 1990, putting this benefit for Commonwealth employees on the same footing as in the private sector. The payment of lump sums on retirement instead of pensions brings forward expenditure. If all transferees were given immediate access to employer-financed lump sums from age 55 with a full credit for past service, the impact on the 1990-91 Budget outlays would be unacceptably high. Budget outlays could increase by up to $300m. For this reason, it has been necessary to phase in access to lump sums in the new scheme.

Lump sum benefits will be available only to members aged 64 and over in 1990-91. This age will be reduced progressively on each 1 July, until lump sums are available to members aged 55 and over in 1994-95. The proposed phasing-in arrangements will limit the impact of lump sums on the 1990-91 Budget to an increase of no more than $21m. In aggregate, Budget outlays are estimated to increase by $131.8m in 1990-91, $147.6m in 1991-92 and $179.2m in 1992-93. However, while net costs for existing members are the same in both schemes, there will be significant savings in respect of future employees.

The cost to employers of superannuation for new entrants will fall from 13.1 per cent to 10.7 per cent of salaries, after allowing for tax and social security clawbacks and for increased coverage of casual and temporary employees. This is a saving of 18 per cent, or 2.4 per cent of salaries. Ultimately, this saving will be reflected in the Budget outlays, which will fall significantly. The new scheme entails some significant changes to the administration of Commonwealth superannuation. The legislation for the new scheme is comparatively simple. Details of the scheme are spelled out in the trust deed and rules included as a schedule to the Bill.

A part time board of trustees, with equal numbers of employer and employee representatives and an independent chairperson, will be established to oversee the new scheme. This is consistent with the thrust of the occupational superannuation standards legislation that responsibility for fund administration and control be placed in the hands of fund trustees. The joint employer-employee trustees will have an obligation to protect members' interests. This will be reinforced with an extensive internal review mechanism.

These arrangements bring Commonwealth employees into the mainstream of Australian superannuation practice, and place their superannuation arrangements on the same footing as arrangements in the private sector. However, appropriate accountability to the Parliament will be maintained. Any changes to the trust deed or rules will be by way of disallowable instruments.

The new scheme is fully in accord with the Government's social justice strategy. The new scheme will substantially improve equity in Commonwealth superannuation. Membership of the scheme will be open to almost all employees, regardless of their employment status. Benefits will be related much more directly to the aggregate period of membership, whether served in one period or in broken periods. Broken periods of service will no longer adversely affect benefits. The significant indirect discrimination against women in the existing scheme will be substantially eliminated.

The reform of Commonwealth superannuation has major financial implications for a very large number of Commonwealth employees. Precise individual entitlements depend on the fine detail of what is a very complex package. For this reason, I have decided to introduce this legislation at this early stage.

While the basic thrust of the new scheme is in the rules forming part of the schedule to the Bill, the rules are not yet complete. For example, the treatment of acquired immune deficiency syndrome in the new scheme will be determined following consultation on a voluntary code of practice. The rules on partial invalidity pensions and part time temporary and casual employees have yet to be drafted. Some other details are yet to be incorporated. For example, people whose transfer credit from the existing scheme exceeds the maximum benefit under the new scheme will be paid a retirement benefit that fully reflects their transfer credit.

There are also consequential amendments required to the Superannuation Act 1976 which will be introduced in the autumn sittings. This will include legislation to empower the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust to operate as a more general funds manager. The Government's policy statement Reform of Commonwealth Superannuation has been well received.

The new scheme has been accepted by the Australian Council of Trade Unions and affiliates, and there has been broad support for the crackdown on invalidity abuse. At present, there is no reason to alter any aspect of the announced package. However, a period of examination over the next few months may well lead to technical improvements in the detailed implementation arrangements.

By introducing the Bill for the new scheme now, honourable members and affected individuals will have the maximum opportunity to examine the detail before the legislation is considered for passage next year. During this period of examination, the Government is prepared to consider any submission on the detailed implementation of the reforms, as long as such submissions are consistent with the package as announced in the policy statement of 15 October and, most importantly, do not increase the costs of the arrangements. The Government will introduce any consequential amendments in the autumn sittings. I commend the Bill to the House. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.

DEBATE.TITLE: FITOUT WORKS AT BOX HILL AND MOONEE PONDS, VICTORIA, ADELAIDE AND PERTH FOR THE AUSTRALIAN TAXATION OFFICE

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Approval of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: Fitout works at Box Hill and Moonee Ponds, Victoria, Adelaide and Perth for Australian Taxation Office.

This is a proposal for fit-out works in six pre-commitment lease office buildings at Box Hill and Moonee Ponds in Melbourne, and at two locations each in Perth and Adelaide. Since 1975 the Australian Taxation Office has been decentralising its larger offices from the central business districts of major cities to suburban or country sites in an effort to bring staff closer to their work and to provide a better service to taxpayers. The Commonwealth leases the base buildings designed to accommodate the Australian Taxation Office. The special purpose fit-outs are designed to cater for the Taxation Office's computer re-equipment program. Each location will be similar and will provide some 20,000 square metres of office space. The fit-out work will be designed and constructed by Australian Construction Services (ACS) with building management input from the Australian Property Group, both divisions of my Department.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't you like the private sector?

—On 18 June 1989 the House agreed to refer this proposal to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works. In the report tabled on the twenty-eighth of this month, the Committee concluded that the accommodation requirement will provide a better working environment for Australian Taxation Office staff. They will lead to improvements in efficiency and productivity and provide a better service to the public. The Australian Taxation Office has assured the Committee that it will conduct extensive discussions with staff and unions regarding the details of the fit-out. The Public Works Committee has recommended that fit-out works in six leased office buildings proceed at an estimated cost of $46.1m at July 1989 prices.

SPEECH.PARA: With regard to the comment made by the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale), as usual the actual work of implementing the fit-outs is expected to be tendered out to the private sector, as it always is.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the design?

—No, I said that the design would probably be done in ACS, did I not? But the actual construction work is to be done by the private sector. In many cases it is done in the private sector, but not always. I commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wooldridge Dr M.R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition does not oppose this motion. However, as Box Hill is in my electorate, I will make a few brief statements about the Australian Taxation Office to be built there. This office comprises some 22,000 square metres, which in any place would cause an enormous impact on the local community. This was one of three competing sites chosen. I believe that this one was chosen largely due to the skill of Mr Bill Heath, one of the local estate agents, who helped put the site together.

SPEECH.PARA: I have followed this matter with some interest ever since the Treasurer (Mr Keating) walked into my electorate three days before the last election and promised a tax office. Some people might come into an electorate and promise a new child-care centre or some money to fix up the roads; it was interesting that the Treasurer should promise a tax office. Tax offices are about as popular as double-breasted Italian suits in my electorate. Anyway, I think it was worth about 500 votes. After the Treasurer made this promise, nothing happened; it was very quiet. In fact, tenders were only called on 10 October 1988.

On making inquiries of local people, I found that when the Treasurer had made his promise plans had been quite well advanced and the Treasury had made tentative approaches to a number of local estate agents. I was a bit puzzled why there should have been a 15-month delay before tenders came out. On making further inquiries, I found that the Government was disinclined to put a new tax office in a newly-won Liberal electorate. So I am thrilled that reality has finally forced the Government to put this office in what is the largest regional centre outside the central business district, and I am very pleased to see the matter finally coming through the House.

DEBATE.TITLE: HOUSING DEVELOPMENTS BY THE DEFENCE HOUSING AUTHORITY AT LAVERTON AND MACLEOD, VICTORIA, AND BULLSBROOK, WESTERN AUSTRALIA

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Reference of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Housing developments by the Defence Housing Authority at Laverton and Macleod, Victoria, and Bullsbrook, Western Australia.

In January 1988, this Government established the Defence Housing Authority as the first step towards providing a better standard and an increased choice of housing for Defence personnel and their families consistent with community standards. The past 30 years has seen a significant increase in problems associated with Defence housing to the point where today nearly 50 per cent of Defence homes require either substantial improvements and repairs or replacement.

TALK.START.PARA: —How could you have let it get to that state?

—I said that this has occurred over the last 30 years. On its establishment, the Defence Housing Authority took over responsibility for some 23,000 houses and has a current investment program in excess of $100m per annum. In line with our commitment to improve housing for Defence families, the Defence Housing Authority recently purchased a 32.5-hectare site at Laverton in Victoria and a 21-hectare site at Bullsbrook in Western Australia. The Authority will also acquire a 50-hectare site in Macleod, Victoria, estimated to be valued at $135m. The total price of these three properties is estimated to be in the order of $18m.

SPEECH.PARA: The Defence Housing Authority intends to develop these sites under arrangements with private sector developers. I am sure the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale) will be happy about that. The benefits of such arrangements which utilise private sector expertise are twofold. Firstly, it will provide significant opportunities for local private sector companies and employment for between 200 and 270 people in each area. Secondly, it will assist in the Defence Housing Authority's mission to integrate Defence and civilian housing and provide a greater housing choice for Defence families. It is expected that ultimate development of these three sites will yield some 920 to 950 houses at a total cost of $145m. Of this total, some 400 houses will be owned by the Defence Housing Authority with 100 each at Laverton and Bullsbrook and 200 at Macleod.

The Laverton site, which will yield 400 lots, is located close to existing Defence employment centres and it is planned to commence subdivisional development about mid-1990. The Macleod site, which is part of the Simpson Army Barracks, will yield up to 440 lots and is situated 18 kilometres east of Melbourne. Development plans currently include generous open space, an ornamental lake, retention of significant river red gums and a range of community facilities. The site is planned to be developed in four stages with the first stage commencing in mid-1990 and the first homes being available toward the end of 1990. The Bullsbrook site will provide alternative housing to the ex-Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement houses purchased by the Defence Housing Authority in February of this year. The land, which is adjacent to the ex-Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement houses, will yield about 185 allotments, of which 100 will be retained by the Authority for the construction of project homes. Construction of major infrastructure and the subdivision can commence early in 1990. The Authority expects that the first homes will be occupied by Defence families in the third quarter of 1990.

All three projects will be subject to the relevant State planning and rezoning process. The two Victorian projects are presently zoned for Commonwealth Defence purposes and Bullsbrook is partly zoned residential and partly rural. All projects will be zoned residential within State legislation. For all projects, the due process of public comment and environmental impact under the relevant State legislation will be observed.

Community needs at the Macleod development may require some shops and a child-care centre, whereas investigations currently under way on the Bullsbrook proposal suggest the development is not large enough to require additional community facilities. The need for additional community facilities at Laverton is currently being investigated. I table selected drawings of the proposed work, and commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the referral of the proposal before the House regarding the provision of Defence housing at Laverton and Macleod in Victoria and Bullsbrook in Western Australia. Together with yesterday's proposal relating to the development of Defence housing in the Sydney area brought forward by the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West), this development is sorely needed. Today's statement by the Minister paraphrases much of his statement of yesterday relating to the Defence Housing Authority proposal in the Sydney area.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister mentions the provision of child-care and shopping facilities at the Macleod and Laverton sites. Under Opposition policy the provision of family day care, occasional care and long-term child-care with improved access for the children of Defence Force personnel will be facilitated.

Additionally, the Opposition will encourage private enterprise to establish adequate shopping facilities on or adjacent to bases where such facilities are not readily available. I add for the Minister's sake that, contrary to his pronouncements that additional facilities are not needed in the Bullsbrook area, my information is that they are in fact needed. A visit to RAAF base Pearce and the Bullsbrook area would confirm this to the Minister and his colleague, the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Simmons). The Opposition fully supports the motion before the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question that is before us in this legislation is that of membership of student bodies-student unions or guilds or whatever one wishes to call them. In the end, the argument that exists between the Opposition and ourselves is whether we should give priority to and whether it is desirable that there should be strong, democratic, viable student representation that should have a say in the running of our tertiary institutions.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, the view put from this side of the House is that that is a priority and that it is necessary that there be automatic membership of student bodies, just as one may choose to be a member of any group or association within the community. One of the requirements is that one should pay a fee. The fee suggested by the Opposition, of up to $300, is excessive. The University of Western Australia asked for a fee of $106 and Curtin University asked for a fee of $105. For that amount of money substantial benefits are provided for students. The honourable member for Lowe (Dr Woods) said that we should argue for consistency. I made a point in relation to that earlier in the debate, and I will make it again. If one wishes to argue for consistency, equally, those in the community who are childless should say, `None of my taxation revenue should go towards child-care' and those in the community who choose not to have children should be able to say, `None of my taxation revenue should go towards providing for education'. Equally, those who are young, like me, and not in receipt of a pension, should be able to say, `None of my taxation revenue should go towards providing for pensions'.

That is absurd. It is not a proposition that the Opposition accepts. If members of the Opposition come to this place and say that we should argue for consistency on this issue, they need to be consistent themselves. If one looks at the policy traditionally pursued by the Liberal component of the student body in Western Australia, which now controls the guild of undergraduates at the University of Western Australia, one does not find a whimper on this issue. When members of the Opposition are in power we do not hear anything about the undesirability of compulsory membership, but when they see fit, they take another position.

Membership of a student body by those who are required to pay a fee should provide for a democratically elected body, and that is the case. It should provide an opportunity for members of the student body to change the membership should they see fit. Indeed, it does. In exactly the same way as any citizen of Australia can choose, if he or she wants, not to vote in a Federal election, so, too, can members of the student body if they choose to take that course of action. But the suggestion that there should not be adequate representation of students as to the way in which their institutions are run is something from the past. It is typical of members of the Opposition that they carp about this issue, which, if one looks at the history of the Fraser Government, is not an issue that was pursued in seven years when they controlled this place and the other place.

Why has this issue been raised in the House today? It is because there is an opportunity to score some political points in New South Wales. The honourable member for Lowe suggests that Queensland is also taking this action. After the weekend the issue will not be a problem in Queensland; so we will have one State government which wishes to challenge the autonomy of the institutions. The institutions agree with this. They will impose and collect the fee. The decision is not made by the Federal Government. The suggestion that we are interfering is not accurate or true. People need to understand that the institutions agree with this. The vice-chancellors have said that they think it appropriate.

This provides the opportunity for the student bodies to have democratic representation; it provides the students with counselling services and with an opportunity to have a say in the running of their institution. If the students disagree with some things, they have representation on all of the senate committees which run the university, college of advanced education, or whatever it might be. That our opponents should see something sinister in this is an issue which we have some difficulty with. We are about providing for fundamental and reasonable autonomy for institutions. We are about providing for student bodies that can have a say in the running of their institutions. We do not think these student bodies should be in some way emaciated. We see these student bodies as requiring assistance and requiring the membership to be wholehearted. I have a great deal of support for the legislation and I hope that Opposition members will take the view that it is important that students should be represented in the running of their institutions.

TALK.START.PARA: —In other debates in this place in the last few days the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) has had occasion to refer to the politics of the big lie and has given some instances of that in relation to the Federal Government and how this Hawke Government will make statements about its intentions, policies and one thing and another when the truth is otherwise.

SPEECH.PARA: I was amazed to hear the honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth) say that this Government is about giving universities autonomy. It is about nothing of the sort. Action after action of the Hawke Government in the tertiary education area has been about forcing institutions to do things that they would prefer not to do. He referred to the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee. The Vice-Chancellors Committee has made plenty of critical comments about this Government's policy in relation to tertiary education and coercion. The reason the Government would bring coercion to bear in relation to membership of student unions is that it knows very well that if students could vote with their feet they would not join these student unions while their money was being spent on some of the activities in which some of the unions have indulged in the past. No-one doubts that there is a need for certain facilities at tertiary institutions but it has been a matter of great controversy and conflict that money given to a student union-and presumably for facilities for the students-has gone to political activities in relation to the Palestine Liberation Organisation, for example, and other quite disgraceful activities in university terms. A lot of universities and vice-chancellors have been gutless on the issue-and I do not mind saying it.

I want to draw particular attention to a situation in the Gold Coast College of Advanced Education, which is in my electorate. It is due to graduate its first students this year. It was established three years ago and is growing extremely rapidly. It anticipates that in a very short time it will have reached a very large enrolment figure, which is not surprising. One of the great difficulties of being a member of parliament representing the Gold Coast area is persuading governments that figures do not lie. Part of the Gold Coast lies in my electorate of Moncrieff; the rest lies in the electorate of McPherson. Over the years predictions have been made about growth on the Gold Coast, all of which have come true. The current prediction is that by the turn of the century the present population of the Gold Coast will have grown from a quarter of a million to half a million. There has been an urgent need for tertiary education facilities on the Gold Coast for some time. I firmly believe that the only thing that pushed this Government into making the decision to go ahead with the Gold Coast CAE was that the setting up of the Bond University was announced. It was subsequent to the announcement of Australia's first private university to be established on the Gold Coast that the Government finally was pushed to make a decision to establish the Gold Coast College of Advanced Education.

The college's growth is very much under threat at the moment, and I want to refer to that. Despite its rapid growth and previously approved programs, both in development of courses and in capital programs that go with them, thanks to this Government the college has lost its 1989 capital funding and its 1990 capital funding is in doubt. I have drawn attention to this on two previous occasions this year in speeches in the House on 16 June and 26 October.

I want to put on the record what has actually been transpiring between the Commonwealth Government and the State Government on this issue. I will quote principally from relevant correspondence and then indicate what all this means in relation to the Gold Coast College of Advanced Education. In June the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) tabled a higher education funding document which showed that funding for the Gold Coast College of Advanced Education was to be reviewed. At the time I objected to this on the grounds that a decision had been made that the college would enter into an amalgamation with either Griffith University or the University of Queensland-that decision had been conveyed to the Minister-the delay in the funding having been justified by the fact that previously there was some doubt as to whether it would enter the unified national system of tertiary education.

On 24 July this year, the Queensland Minister for Education, Youth and Sport, Hon. Brian Littleproud, wrote to the Federal Minister for Education requesting that funding for stage 2 of the teaching building of the Gold Coast College of Advanced Education be released. He said:

I am writing at this time to seek your agreement to release these two buildings to enable an early start on their construction. Further delays will make the provision of accommodation for students in 1990 extremely difficult.

The GCCAE is currently engaged in serious discussions with the Brisbane universities with the view to establishing a relationship which will enable it to become a member of the Unified National System. While this process will possibly take a further extended period of time there is no doubt that such a relationship is inevitable.

Under these circumstances I would appreciate your early approval to the release of the funding for these two buildings, one of which includes a significant contribution from the Queensland Government to enable the commencement of basic nurse education from the beginning of 1990.
On 26 July, the Chairman of the Gold Coast CAE Council wrote to the Minister and said, in part:

. . . I write to express our continuing concern at the delay in funding for Stage 2 of the College's Capital Building Fund. As the Council has now clearly resolved to seek a University College affiliation with a Brisbane University and this resolution has been endorsed by the Queensland Cabinet there appears to us no valid reason why funds for Stage 2 cannot be made available.

In respect of a University College affiliation the Gold Coast College of Advanced Education is currently having discussions with both the University of Queensland and Griffith University. It is the Council's expectation that an intent to affiliate with one of these institutions acceptable to both governing bodies, the Queensland Government and the Commonwealth Government, will be reached no later than 17 September 1989. I would add that the major impediment to finalisation of this process is the matter of financial support from the Commonwealth Government to consolidating institutions. Quite rightly the institutions believe that there is an expectation for appropriate support for such activities adumbrated in the White Paper.

At its meeting on Wednesday 16 August the Council of the Gold Coast College of Advanced Education resolved that it would advise the Council of Griffith University that it wishes to enter a stage of detailed and exclusive negotiations with Griffith University in respect of the Gold Coast College of Advanced Education becoming an affiliated University College of Griffith University. In addition it resolved that the Joint Working Party already established by the two Councils should proceed expeditiously to finalise a Memorandum of Agreement between Griffith University and the Gold Coast College of Advanced Education.

He indicated to the Minister that he had conveyed the content of the resolution to the Chancellor of Griffith University, to the University of Queensland and to the State Minister for Education. He continued:

In view of the Council's resolution and the fact that a Joint Working Party has been established by the Councils of Griffith University and the Gold Coast College of Advanced Education I wish to seek your approval for the release of Capital Funds for Stage 2 of the Gold Coast CAE Building Program.

On 22 August, Minister Littleproud wrote to Minister Dawkins referring to his letter of 24 July and seeking urgent release of funds for teaching buildings. In the letter he stated:

I understand that the Joint Working Party already established by the two Councils is now proceeding to finalise a Memorandum of Agreement between Griffith University and the Gold Coast College of Advanced Education.

In the light of the above determinations I write to ask again for the expected funds associated with the Gold Coast College of Advanced Education building program to be released so that the building program which has been `frozen' can now proceed. On 23 August, one B. C. Milligan, First Assistant Secretary of the Higher Education Division of the Department of Employment, Education and Training, Central Office, wrote to the Chairman of the Gold Coast College of Advanced Education referring to the Chairman's letter to the Minister of 26 July about the funds. He stated:
I am replying on the Minister's behalf.
In part the letter states:

I am encouraged to learn that the College is engaged in discussions with Brisbane universities and that a firm arrangement is not far off. The Department is not, however in a position to release further funds to the project until arrangements for the College to become part of the unified national system are formalised in Heads of Agreement documentation.

That was the first time the condition that formal heads of agreement had to be actually signed before funds would be released had been conveyed to any of the parties in this amalgamation. On 29 August Minister Dawkins wrote to Minister Littleproud referring to Minister Littleproud's letter of 24 July about funding. In part he stated:

I am encouraged to learn that the College is engaged in discussions with Brisbane universities and gain the impression from your letter that a firm arrangement is not far off. I would therefore prefer to wait until a formal agreement is made, between the College and one of the universities, before releasing the capital funds.

On 30 August the Vice-Chancellor of Griffith University wrote to Minister Dawkins to say that he was confirming discussions with the Gold Coast college and that there was a positive affirmation on its part:

. . . to achieve a productive and mutually beneficial University College relationship with Griffith University. The University, for its part, having proposed such discussions in December, 1988, welcomes the negotiations and is pursuing them as speedily as possible.

There could therefore have been no doubt about the bona fides of all parties in the negotiations. On 13 October, Minister Dawkins wrote to Minister Littleproud referring to Minister Littleproud's letter of 22 August and saying:

By now you will have received my letter of 29 August 1989 which advised that I will wait until the College enters into a formal agreement before releasing the capital funds. That is still my position.
That was the Minister's position, stated several times as from Mr Milligan's letter of 23 August. Following that letter I put a question on notice in which I asked in part:
Has it been a consistent requirement of his-
that is, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training-

that amalgamations of tertiary institutions must proceed to the stage of a Memorandum of Agreement between two institutions before Commonwealth funds for approved capital building programs are released; if not, in which cases have capital building funds been withheld from institutions which have given an undertaking to amalgamate but which have not yet signed a Memorandum of Agreement.

That question remains unanswered. It does not seem to be a very difficult question. As far as I know, no other tertiary institution has had that condition put on it. On 25= October I made a speech to the House on this subject. Subsequent to my speech a letter from Senator Mal Colston appeared in the Gold Coast Bulletin, which in part said:

The CAE is currently discussing amalgamation or merger proposals with Griffith University. The Federal Government cannot however make funds available merely on an undertaking that negotiations are being held with another post-secondary institution. That is no guarantee that an amalgamation or merger would in fact proceed. If an agreement is formally reached with Griffith or any other similar institution, the funding for the CAE's second stage will be made available without question.
The ball is very much in the CAE's court.
I repeat:
If an agreement is formally reached with Griffith or any other similar institution, the funding for the CAE's second stage will be made available without question.
The ball is therefore very much in the CAE's court.
On 8 November, Minister Littleproud wrote to Minister Dawkins and stated:
I have now sighted a signed copy of the Memorandum of Agreement between Griffith University and and the Gold Coast College of Advanced Education.
A copy is attached for your information. I now write to formally request that the funds for growth and capital works at the Gold Coast College should be released.
On 8 November-the same day-the Vice-Chancellor of Griffith University also wrote to Minister Dawkins. He, by the way, faxed his letter to Minister Dawkins on the same day. The letter states:

I am pleased to advise that a Memorandum of Agreement between the University and the Gold Coast College of Advanced Education was entered into by the governing bodies of the institutions on 8 November, 1989. A copy is attached.
The Director of the Gold Coast College of Advanced Education wrote to Minister Dawkins on 9 November saying:

I am pleased to advise that following endorsement by both Councils a Memorandum of Agreement has now been signed whereby the Gold Coast College of Advanced Education will become a University College of Griffith University. A copy of this Memorandum of Agreement is attached.

In view of the fact that the Memorandum of Agreement has now been signed I seek the Minister's approval in releasing Commonwealth Government funds for Stage 2 of the College's Capital Building Program. It is crucial that construction of the buildings in Stage 2 commence as soon as possible in order that the continuing demand for higher education in the Gold Coast region, the State and the Nation can be met.

To date none of these letters from Minister Littleproud, from the Vice-Chancellor of Griffith University or from the Director of the Gold Coast College of Advanced Education has been responded to by Minister Dawkins.

Last week, on Tuesday, 21 November, I contacted Minister Dawkins's office and indicated to him that I would like an appointment to discuss the subject of the funding of capital works for the Gold Coast College of Advanced Education. We arranged that I would have an appointment with him at 3 o'clock on Monday, 27 November. On Monday a message came to my office indicating that the Minister could not keep that appointment and offering that I meet with some of his staff. I said `No' and that I wanted to discuss the subject with him personally, otherwise I would give my views on the subject during this debate. He then wrote a letter dated 27 November, which I received the next day, the twenty-eighth, in which he stated in part:

I have however taken the view that, in cases such as the Gold Coast, where one or more of the parties to a merger are not members of the UNS, capital funds will not be released until all parties have agreed to the terms of a memorandum of agreement and it is clear that any necessary legislation will be passed by the relevant State Government.

I have therefore asked the Queensland Government if it supports the proposed arrangement and for an assurance that it will legislate for the merger. On receipt of that assurance, I will arrange for immediate release of funding for the college's building program.

What absolute rot! In those letters that I have quoted from Minister Dawkins and his officers, time and again they have said that the only condition was a signed memorandum of agreement. I have queried Minister Dawkins whether that condition was put on any other tertiary institution, but that query remains unanswered. Nevertheless, the institutions have now given the Minister a signed memorandum of agreement. Now he says `and'-another condition is added, a condition which has not been adverted to at any stage previously. Nothing could be clearer than the fact that the Queensland Government supports that merger for the purpose of obtaining the funds.
Senator Colston issued a press release on 28 November. Apparently he received the same letter as I did from the Minister. The press release states:

. . . today he [Senator Colston] had been informed by the Federal Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Mr Dawkins, that all that is now required for the capital funding to be released for the Gold Coast CAE is Queensland Government support.

If anything has not been beyond doubt throughout this matter, it is the support of the Queensland Government. The same honourable senator, who a few months earlier wrote letters to the Gold Coast newspapers saying all that was required was the memorandum of agreement and that it was up to the CAE, now alleges that the Queensland Government is holding up the matter. It is nothing of the sort. The press release continues:
I am confident that a Goss led Labor government will provide that assurance without delay.

Despite the fact that the Minister said in the letter to me that he has asked the Queensland Government whether it supports the proposed arrangement, he has not responded to Minister Littleproud. No communication has been sent in response to Mr Littleproud's letter of 8 November. I checked with Minister Littleproud's office this afternoon and his staff checked all sections in case a letter had been sent but had been sidetracked to another office. They went through all their files, but there is no response to the letter of 8 November that went to Mr Dawkins from the Queensland Minister requesting the funding.

This is just a cheap, shabby ploy which, one presumes, has something to do with the Queensland election which is to be held this Saturday. In the meantime, the building of the Gold Coast CAE is being delayed, and that is serious. If the approval had been given three weeks ago when the Queensland Minister requested it of Minister Dawkins, the tenders for those buildings could have been close to finalisation. Tender documents have long since been drawn up. Tenders could have been advertised and they could have now been received. Apparently, we now have to wait until after the State election before this Federal Government will commit itself to funding the building of the Gold Coast CAE, by which time we will be in the pre-Christmas period. The delays that will have been caused because of the Commonwealth Government's shuffling of feet and trying to strike a political pose-this miserable contribution by Minister Dawkins to the Queensland State election-will be very serious indeed. This capital building program should have been under way this year; it should have been finished next year. Students are waiting to enrol at this college.

The Queensland Government has committed millions of dollars for nurse education and it is waiting on this Commonwealth money for those courses to go ahead. There is no doubt at all about the bona fides of the Queensland Government in relation to proceeding with the Gold Coast CAE. The Queensland Government has made it very clear that it was not happy about forced amalgamations, but it has legislated for all the amalgamations for which the final stage of agreement had been reached. It might say that it did not do so willingly and that it is not what it would have chosen to do; but it has acknowledged the fact that such a course has been forced on it by the Federal Government and that it has bowed to pressure placed on it by the Federal Government. It has never given any inkling that it would do anything else in relation to this college.

It is a disgrace that Minister Dawkins should try to hide behind press releases from Senator Colston. It has been left to me to send a copy of the letter I received from Minister Dawkins to Mr Littleproud, otherwise he would not even know that this additional condition had been placed on the funding. He has not received any communication to that effect from the Federal Government. I look forward to discovering whether, for once, the Minister in this place will state where he stands in relation to the Gold Coast College of Advanced Education, quite unequivocally, and regardless of the outcome of next Saturday's election in Queensland. Will this money be provided for the building of the Gold Coast CAE?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 3) is about autonomy for higher education institutions. In short, the Bill is about reducing State government interference in that autonomy. It is about leaving the decisions of institutions, the running of institutions and the decisions that should be made to the institutions themselves rather than having one level of government impose its will and direction upon individual institutions. It is quite right that, if we are to respect autonomy amongst higher education institutions, then we should leave those democratic choices on such matters as the content of courses, assessment of students' progress, the research that is undertaken in these institutions, staff appointments, and so on, to the institutions themselves. I might also include vice-chancellors in those staff appointments. It is still the case in Queensland that two or three vice-chancellors at higher education institutions are not appointed by the institution itself but, rather, they are appointed by a decision of the Queensland Government. I do not suggest that anything improper has taken place in relation to those appointments, but at least they transgress the principle of autonomy for higher education institutions.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the most important freedoms for academics, both students and staff, is the freedom of expression on campus and beyond campus on matters related to education and attendant upon education. This Bill refers to freedom of expression, the right of opinion, and the ability for student bodies to arrange their own affairs. What student bodies can do on campus, whether or not they can impose fees, and how they can spend those fees within certain limits, is determined by the governing council of an institution. So, if an institution decides within its own processes that there should be what have become known as compulsory union fees so that a range of student services can be provided, that decision is made not by government but, rather, by the government of the institution, and it is wrong and improper for governments to interfere with the decision as to whether or not compulsory union fees should be levied.

During this debate there has been a certain amount of sophistry. The Opposition has attempted to oppose the right for there to be compulsory unionism amongst students, but I note that the contributions have been very short. Honourable members opposite have, as did the honourable member of Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan), immediately gone to the topic of education institutions within their own electorates. I have no criticism about that, because it is right and proper for members of this Parliament to express through this House, to the Minister, their concerns about higher education in their own electorate. I will do the same thing later on.

I return to a matter central to this Bill. By opposing this Bill, the Opposition is in fact supporting the heavy hand of government. It is indicating that it is right for the New South Wales Government to interfere with the autonomy of a higher education institution and to say that there shall not be compulsory union fees. It is signalling very strongly that should a Federal Liberal government ever occupy the government benches it would introduce global national legislation to bring about the same effect. The Opposition is signalling that it opposes that form of academic freedom-freedom of the institution to determine a collection through compulsory union fees.

The Opposition has tried to bring in this rather bogus analogy between unionism amongst the trade, craft and guild unions and the student unions. We know that a union is a collection of people, a bringing together of people with a common intent and agenda. That is what is meant by a union, and that is what the students want. It is why students continue to support, almost universally, compulsory student unionism. They know that if they stick together they have the strength to get across their message in their campaign for better deals for education from all governments. They also know that a range of education services, such as counselling and sporting facilities, would not be available from the income of institutions; they are available only because that income is supplemented by student union fees.

When the Opposition talks about academic freedom it talks about it in a very sophistic way. By advocating interference in academic freedom, the Opposition actually puts up an argument for trampling on academic freedom. If Opposition members believe in academic freedom, why do they not believe in the Latin motto, res non verba? Why do deeds not follow their words? We are not talking about compulsory membership of a trade union; we are talking about a different form of union. An analogy can be drawn between those who would like to opt out of paying compulsory fees, which is what the Opposition is arguing for, and those who would like to opt out of paying taxes. Student bodies are elected. They make decisions after an election process. The election is democratic, and if students do not like the result that is their problem. But the result is democratic. Therefore, the decisions of a student body have a legitimate basis for what they do with those student union fees. There are plenty of people in our community who would like to opt out of paying tax. Given the choice, the average person would not pay any tax at all but would still expect a full range of government-provided services. With the elimination of the capital gains tax, we will return to a situation in which the payment of tax will be voluntary for certain wealthy, asset-rich members of society.

I return to the campuses of higher education institutions. If people can choose to opt out of paying compulsory union dues which provide a range of services, we will be in a similar position to that obtaining when people put up the argument that they did not want their taxes to contribute to the Vietnam War. In this Parliament we have heard others say that they do not want their taxes to contribute to Medicare rebates associated with the termination of pregnancy. We cannot opt out of individual spending programs if we are to have a government with a legitimate Budget and a range of programs. Once an institution has declared that it will collect compulsory student union levels, the question of whether students should be able to opt out is raised. We are not talking about those students who have a legitimate conscientious objection. We are talking about the general principle. The exercising of a freedom does not come without responsibility. If one exercises an option not to participate, one also has to consider why a choice to opt out exists. I do not think people have a right or licence to ignore involvement.

The honourable member for Lowe (Dr Woods) presented three basic arguments, which were carried by others in the Opposition, as to why there should not be compulsory union fees. One argument was that only 20 to 25 per cent of the student body vote. Let us compare this figure to other election figures. In Australia, we have compulsory elections. Many countries overseas do not have compulsory elections. The turnout at such an important and significant election as the national election in the United Kingdom is only something like 50 to 60 per cent of voters. Even if there is only a 20 to 25 per cent turnout for student elections, that is no argument against compulsory union fees. It is an argument for activists to involve others. It is an argument for those who complain about the decisions made by the 20 to 25 per cent of voters, therefore the activists, to become more involved. It is certainly irrelevant to whether there should be a compulsory fee.

The second argument put forward by the honourable member for Lowe was that there are students who do not agree with the political opinions expressed by student union bodies. It seems to me that anyone who does not agree with the Government, the student representatives, those who have successfully voted through the ballot box on the campus have the right-in fact, the obligation-to carry their complaints into action, to become involved and to work to change the composition of the political majority on that body. In other words, they have an obligation to become involved and to exercise their right to free expression, which is what this Bill is trying to maintain.

The honourable member for Lowe in his third argument said that many students are more concerned with their studies than with involvement in student politic. He said that in a disparaging manner. That may well be true for many, but others go beyond their studies when they assess education and make a contribution to it. They do not see the situation from a `Me only, I must succeed' point of view. They see education in broader terms. They see the right of access to education going beyond those within the campuses of higher education institutions to those who have missed out. They are the ones who are campaigning to the Government and to the Opposition, through student bodies, for a better deal for students and for higher education itself. A government of the day might not like it, but that does not mean that its embarrassment and discomfort will support the argument for reducing the income to institutions via higher education compulsory union fees. Not one complaint has been sent to my electorate office about compulsory union fees. Therefore, I suggest that there is no mandate for the Opposition to oppose this Bill. In fact, it has a mandate to support it. It is trying to hijack the debate by misrepresenting it with some loose analogy with unionism generally. It is trying to stifle any political input into the education debate.

The honourable member for Moncrieff said that she found that many undesirable campaigns-they were her words-took place; yet, as I have said, the way to change campaigns is to change the composition of the union body by becoming involved. But let us look at the campaigns. This Government had to put up with campaigns against its program of introducing the higher education admission charge. We did not squeal about that; we did not cut off their funds and say, `This is undesirable'. We met head on and debated their point of view. Again, when we replaced the higher educations admission charge with the higher education contribution scheme there was a body of opinion on campuses that once again opposed this Government. But we did not go out and cut off funds to student bodies. We believe in the right of criticism and we believe in the right of academic freedom, so we let it go. We won that argument through debate, which is as it should be done.

However, the Opposition knows that it will come up against the full front of a campaign by the student bodies against its proposal to introduce a $1,200 up-front before enrolment charge before people can enter higher education institutions. In other words, under a possible future Liberal government every student who goes to a higher education institution must produce $1,200 before enrolment. That is not to be compared with the Government's program of students not paying until they receive the benefits of higher education. So, really, the hidden agenda of Opposition members is to silence the student bodies and their criticism of the Opposition's $1,200 up-front charge for higher education before the next election. The Opposition is clearly divided in its opinion on the value and the right of academic freedom, and the right of institutions to run their own affairs. I support the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a brief contribution to this debate on the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill for a very strong personal reason, and that is that in the time that I have been in this House, and particularly during the time that I was Leader of the Opposition, I have developed a very close association-and I am very proud to talk about it-with the various Liberal student bodies on the campuses throughout Australia. As the current patron of the Australian Liberal Students Federation, I am more than happy to speak very strongly against this quite outrageous proposal by the Hawke Government. If ever there was a convoluted exercise of logic chopping, it is what we have just heard from the honourable member for Streeton (Mr Lamb). To suggest that the attitude that we take on this measure is an assault on academic freedom is to engage in quintessential logic chopping. What the Government is proposing to do with this measure, through the use of the money power of the Federal Constitution, is coerce the States and tertiary institutions into toeing the line on its own anti-freedom of association ideological commitment.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill is an assault on the principle of freedom of association. What is at risk is not the right of the citizen to selectively decline to pay taxation and to bear the cost of the general services of government. That is sheer sophistry, and the honourable member for Streeton knows it. What is at stake here is the simple principle of freedom of association. Are we or are we not in favour of freedom of association in this country? That is why, over a very long period of time, the Liberal clubs on the campuses of universities and other tertiary institutions throughout Australia fought what was at times a very torrid battle against compulsory unionism and to win the hearts and minds of students on campuses.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have taken it to court.

—Yes, they have taken it to court. I believe they have won the respect of a growing number of people who resent the allocation of their funds to partisan political purposes. The honourable member for Streeton himself will know that, on occasions, the National Union of Students has given money to support particular candidates taking a partisan point of view. SPEECH.PARA: I turn to this tortured argument about the provision of facilities. We had a positively heart-rending contribution from the honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth), who talked about the cold meat pies and the poor facilities provided when he was at university. That provokes recollection of our own experiences. When I attended the University of Sydney law school in the late 1950s it was then, as it now is, physically separate from the main body of the university. The meagre amenities provided then were a very poor recompense for the compulsory fees that were extracted from us, as they have continued to be extracted from generations of students who have attended the University of Sydney. So that kind of argument cuts no ice.

I simply want to put on record in this debate my own very strong personal commitment to the principle of freedom of association for student union bodies. I greatly admire the campaign that has been run by the Liberal clubs and associations throughout Australia over many years, and as patron of the Australian Liberal Students Federation I am very proud of the role that those bodies have played in breaking down and exposing the hypocrisy that lies behind this particular approach. I think it is a very sorry day when this Government proposes to use the money power of the Federal Constitution-that is what it is doing-to coerce State governments and universities into maintaining an insidious form of compulsory unionism. That is what the Government is doing, pure and simple.

I can only say to the Government that the battle on this will go on, because the resentment to compulsory association and the rejection of compulsory unionism throughout the campuses around Australia are very strong and very deep. I totally endorse all of the remarks made by my colleague the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), who has put the Opposition's case in his normally eloquent fashion and who understands a principle when he sees it-unlike the members of the Australian Labor Party who have participated in this debate who, when it comes to associations, put on their old blinkers. I think the Czechs and the East Germans have left Government members behind. On issues like this, Government members run the risk of being a stranded, endangered species. Rhetoric aside-I suppose one is allowed the occasional piece of rhetoric in these matters-what we ought to do is recognise this for what it really is. It is a squalid exercise in compelling people to belong to something against their will. That not only violates my liberal instincts, but also violates the sense of fair play and fair association of the majority of Australians, and that is why we are opposed to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Commonwealth of Australia branch delegation to the Thirty-fourth Commonwealth Parliamentary Conference held in Canberra in September 1988. I ask leave of the House to make a short statement in connection with the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Commonwealth of Australia branch delegation, I present its report on the Thirty-fourth Commonwealth Parliamentary Conference. The Conference held special significance for Australia, being held in our bicentennial year and in our new and permanent Parliament House. I was pleased to have the honour to lead the delegation.

SPEECH.PARA: Delegations from 104 parliaments and legislatures attended the Conference, along with 106 observers from international organisations and Commonwealth Parliamentary Association (CPA) member branches. There was a total of 520 participants, including spouses and unofficial observers. Visitors came from every part of the world: Asia, from Singapore to India; the Caribbean; Europe and the Mediterranean; Africa; North America; and the Australasian-Pacific area. As well as diverse geographic locations, the delegations came from the broad spectrum of parliamentary systems, including republics, monarchies under Queen Elizabeth II and national monarchies. Sir Ninian Stephen, the then Governor-General, drew on the theme of the geographic diversity of the countries attending the Conference in his opening address. He told delegates that their presence was abundant testimony to the enduring vitality of parliamentary institutions throughout the Commonwealth of Nations. He encouraged those present to draw hope from the gathering and the agenda that it had set itself, that the evils of the world could be eradicated.

The Conference deliberations consisted of four plenary sessions and six panel sessions. The first plenary session, that on international peace and security, was presented by His Excellency Shridath Ramphal, who presented an historical perspective on the world's troublespots, before addressing the theme of the plenary session. He commented on the need for circumspection in talking of peace, especially in regard to the approximately 20 million people who have died as a result of armed conflicts in the postwar era, mainly in developing countries. He called on the Commonwealth to be a standard-bearer for peace and on each parliament to reaffirm the Goa declaration.

Among the key topics covered in the other sessions were drugs and what the Commonwealth can do to curb drug abuse and drug-trafficking, the spread of acquired immune deficiency syndrome, the current General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade discussions, the negative effects of the declining world economy on women and young people, and the establishment of a parliamentary branch of Amnesty International. The Commonwealth of Australia branch delegation participated fully in the plenary and panel sessions. As members of the delegation of one of the host branches, we felt we had a special reponsibility, as well as the usual obligation to participate fully. We felt an additional obligation to our guests to assist and encourage them in their participation. As well as the main proceedings, there were other activities associated with the Conference. The Eighth Commonwealth Parliamentary Conference of Members from Small Countries and the meetings of the Society of Clerks-at-the- Table are of particular note.

The Conference, in all its facets, was an outstanding success. The delegation wishes to record its appreciation of the efforts of the State branches and their executive committees and staff, Senator Sibraa, President of the Senate, the Conference Coordinating Committee headed by Mr Browning, and Mr Kieran Schneeman, and the staff of the Parliamentary Relations Office. I also thank Mr Mark McRae, the secretary to the delegation, for his efforts prior to, and during, the Conference. I would also like to thank all of those other workers behind the scenes who worked arduously throughout the whole Conference and late into the night and early hours of the morning. Their efforts should also be recorded here tonight because the work that is done behind the scenes by those people is never really appreciated by delegates and other people who attend conferences. I was honoured to have the opportunity to lead the branch delegation, and I wish to thank the deputy leader, the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), and my fellow delegates, both Commonwealth and State, for their support and cooperation.
