SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak on the matter of identification by the media of witnesses to violent crimes. Last month in my electorate a shooting took place near premises known to police to be a centre for criminal activity. The victim had suffered five gunshot wounds and was assisted by one of my constituents who had been nearby when the incident occurred and had clearly seen the two men leaving the scene.

SPEECH.PARA: In the chaos that soon followed, with the arrival of police, ambulance personel, media and numerous spectators, my constituent was questioned by a number of people about what had taken place. He became aware that one of the questioners was a reporter and that his replies were being filmed and recorded on videotape. The man had at no time identified himself as a reporter nor asked for permission to record an interview. At this point, my constituent stopped speaking and moved away, realising the implications of speaking publicly. He was approached several times by the reporter from Channel 9, but declined to speak further and left the scene after giving statements to the police. The shooting at this time was considered by police to be related to criminal activity, possibly a gangland or underworld incident.

Channel 9 ran the interview on its 6 o'clock news bulletin that night, with the name of the witness screened in bold letters while he spoke, instantly placing him and his family in potential danger and subjecting them to fear and uncertainty. My constituent immediately contacted the police to ask who had made his name available to the media, since he knew he had given no details. It appears that the reporter had requested and obtained the witness's name from the police.

The actions of Channel 9 and the police raise very serious issues in relation to the treatment of witnesses to crime. Firstly, the failure of the Channel 9 reporter to identify himself, a procedure which is laid down in the code of ethics of the Australian Journalists Association, point 8 of which states:
They shall identify themselves and their employers before obtaining any interview for publication or broadcast.

The reporter involved quite clearly breached this code of ethics, but I believe the decision of the news department in publishing the witness's name, without first checking whether consent had been obtained, constituted a thoughtless and irresponsible act which could easily have had disastrous consequences. As it was, the family lived in fear for some days, believing their lives could be at risk.

This raises the question of self-regulation by the media. One would expect that, in such circumstances firm operational procedures would be in place which would ensure that no interview would be broadcast or identification of witnesses made without the prior permission of the person involved. Such people are often shocked and confused, in situations totally unfamiliar to them, and cannot be expected to be aware of cameras and reporters, let alone the implications of speaking about what they have witnessed. Speaking into the camera and providing details of one's name is taken by media organisations as consent to broadcast an interview. It is therefore essential that reporters clearly identify themselves before conducting an interview and only seek details of a witness's name from the person involved. In this case, both these obligations were breached.

I would suggest it should be a requirement of all media organisations that full permission be obtained before an interview with a witness to a crime is broadcast, or reference made to the witness's name, yet it appears that the media organisations place the onus on the person interviewed to request an interview not be broadcast. This is a completely unsatisfactory and unreasonable expectation, given the state of mind of most ordinary people who are confronted with violent and frightening incidents such as this one.

The second very serious area of concern in this case is the release of the witness's name to the media by the police. This action can only be described as irresponsible in the extreme. Witnesses to such incidents come forward and provide information to the police in the expectation that this information will be confidential. Police officers would surely be aware of the risk to witnesses in situations where the offender is still at large and knows he has been clearly identified, particularly in a case where it is believed that gangland figures are involved.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 30 October 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Minister's Department employ Peat Marwick Hungerfords to undertake a review of language services provisions; if so, did the review cost $79,000.

(2) If such a review has been undertaken, has it been completed; if so, (a) has the report been made publicly available, (b) if it has been made publicly available, (i) when and (ii) to whom was it made available, (c) if it was not made publicly available, why not and (d) if it contained recommendations, have they been implemented.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Peat Marwick Hungerford Management Consultants were commissioned to review options for rationalising Government provision of language services by the Commonwealth and the States; the fee involved is $79,000.

(2) The review has not yet been finalised. When completed the review will be available to relevant Departments and instrumentalities but, because of the costs involved, is not intended for general publication. The completed review would likely be available to those requesting access to it under the Freedom of Information Act 1982.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 31 October 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: What is the estimated number of permanent residents in Australia who are eligible for citizenship but who have not obtained or applied for it.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: It is estimated that there are about one million permanent residents in Australia who are eligible for citizenship but who have not obtained it. Further to this, there are currently nearly 25,000 applications for Australian citizenship awaiting approval, some of these covering more than one person.
